{{Infobox person | name = Tom Segev | image = Tom Segev (2011).jpg | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1945|3|01|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Jerusalem]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] | death_date = | death_place = | other_names = | known_for = | occupation = Journalist, historian }}
'''Tom Segev''' ({{lang-he|תום שגב}}; born March 1, 1945) is an Israeli historian, author and journalist. He is associated with Israel's [[New Historians]], a group challenging many of the country's traditional narratives.
==Biography== Tom Segev was born in [[Jerusalem]] to parents who had fled Nazi Germany in 1933. He earned a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in history and political science from the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] and a [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in history from [[Boston University]] in the 1970s.<ref>[http://globetrotter.berkeley.edu/people4/Segev/segev-con1.html Conversation with Tom Segev, p. 1 of 7<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Journalism career== Segev worked during the 1970s as a correspondent for [[Maariv (newspaper)|Maariv]] in Bonn.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1081754.html I didn't have the guts, Haaretz, April 28, 2009]</ref> He was a visiting professor at [[Rutgers University]] (2001–2002),<ref>[http://www.salon.com/books/int/2001/12/08/palestine Salon.com Books | Beyond tribalism]</ref> the [[University of California at Berkeley]] (2007)<ref>[http://globetrotter.berkeley.edu/people7/Segev/segev07-con0.html Conversation with Tom Segev (2007), cover page<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and [[Northeastern University]], where he taught a course on [[Holocaust denial]]. He writes a weekly column for the newspaper ''[[Haaretz]]''. His books have appeared in fourteen languages.
In ''The Seventh Million: The Israelis and the Holocaust'' (1993), Segev explores the decisive impact of the Holocaust on the identity, ideology and politics of Israel. Although controversial, it was praised by [[Elie Wiesel]] in the ''Los Angeles Times'' Book Review.<ref>{{vcite journal |author=Elie Wiesel |title=The Land That Broke Its Promise THE SEVENTH MILLION: The Israelis and the Holocaust, By Tom Segev |articletype=Book Review |journal=LA Times |journal.= |edition= |journalformat=Internet |date=1992 |update= |archiveurl= |archivedate=1997 |accessdate=2010-04-18 |volume= |issue= |pages= |language=English |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/doc/282068355.html}}</ref>
In ''One Palestine, Complete: Jews and Arabs Under the British Mandate'', a ''New York Times'' Editor's Choice Best Book (2000) and a recipient of the National Jewish Book Award, Segev describes the era of the British Mandate in Palestine (1917–1948).
Segev's history of the social and political background of the [[Six-Day War]], ''1967: Israel, the War, and the Year That Transformed the Middle East'' (2006) states that there was no existential threat to Israel from a military point of view. Segev also doubts that the Arab neighbours would have really attacked Israel. Still, there were large segments of the Israeli population that had a real fear that the Egyptians and Syrians would eliminate them. This would have increased the pressure for the Israeli government in such a way that it opted for a preemptive attack. The attack by the Jordanian army to West Jerusalem would have provided a welcoming reason to invade East Jerusalem, according to Segev. Even though the occupation of East Jerusalem was not politically planned, the author considers it was always desired. In February 2018 Segev published a biography of David Ben-Gurion.
==Praise and criticism== The book "Israel, the War, and the Year That Transformed the Middle East" has been described by the historian [[Saul Friedländer]] as "probably the best book on those most fateful days in the history of Israel".<ref>[https://www.amazon.de/1967-Israel-Year-Transformed-Middle/dp/product-description/0805070575 ''1967: Israel, the War, and the Year That Transformed the Middle East''], by Tom Segev.</ref>
[[Ethan Bronner]] in ''[[The New York Times Book Review]]'' wrote: "It does not tell the whole story of the war, barely focusing on Arab activity... What interests Mr. Segev is Israel: its moods, debates, generation gaps and anxieties" and that "You need not agree with Mr. Segev’s conclusions on how things could have been done differently to benefit from his research and narrative. If you plan to read only one book on the 1967 war, this is not it. It is too narrowly focused. At the same time Mr. Segev makes a compelling and fresh case that the war was at least partly a result of a delicate and vulnerable moment in Israeli history" and that Segev's exploration "is — while too long — persuasive and engaging".<ref>Ethan Bronner, [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/06/18/books/18bron.html?pagewanted=all Holding a Mirror Up to Israeli Destiny, the Past and the Prologue], ''The New York Times'', 18 June 2007</ref>
[[L. Carl Brown]] wrote in ''[[Foreign Affairs]]'' "The author of One Palestine, Complete: Jews and Arabs Under the British Mandate has written another masterful history" in a review of Segev's book ''1967: Israel, the War, and the Year That Transformed the Middle East''.<ref>[http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/62788/l-carl-brown/1967-israel-the-war-and-the-year-that-transformed-the-middle-eas 1967: Israel, the War, and the Year That Transformed the Middle East], L. Carl Brown, ''Foreign Affairs''</ref>
Writing in ''International Socialist Review'' (a paper "dedicated to advancing socialist theory and practice"),<ref>{{cite web|title=About the International Socialist Review|url=https://isreview.org/about|publisher=ISR|accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> Hadas Thier found the 688-page book "at times a tediously detailed read with thin analysis" but called it "an indispensable contribution". He summarised the book by saying "His focus on Israeli archival material should leave no trace of doubt that Israeli leaders knew that the war was not a defensive necessity, that it would be easily won, and that it was fought on the basis of cynical and strategic considerations of the state."<ref>[http://isreview.org/issue/59/unmasking-six-day-war "Unmasking the Six-Day War"] ''1967: Israel, the War and the Year that Transformed the Middle East'' by Tom Segev, Review by Hadas Thier, Issue #59: Reviews.</ref>
For ''[[The Washington Post]] Book World'', [[Michael Oren]], an Israeli politician, historian and author of ''[[Six Days of War]]'', gave Segev's ''1967'' a scathing review, writing, "Laboring to prove his point forces Segev not only to contradict himself but also to commit glaring oversights." He also says that "by disregarding the Arab dynamic and twisting his text to meet a revisionist agenda, he undermines his attempt to reach a deeper understanding of the war. Such an understanding is vital if Arabs and Israelis are to avoid similar clashes in the future and peacefully co-exist."<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/07/AR2007060701872.html "Who Started It?"] ''1967 - Israel, the War, and the Year That Transformed the Middle East'' by Tom Segev, reviewed by Michael Oren. ''The Washington Post, June 10, 2007.</ref> (In an interview in the online magazine ''Salon'', Oren subsequently said of Segev (who has a doctorate in history) "[He] is a journalist. He's not really a trained historian.")<ref>[http://www.salon.com/2002/06/12/oren/ "Six days that shook the world"], ''Salon'', Suzy Hansen, 13 June, 2002</ref>
[[Benny Morris]] also criticized the book in a review in ''[[The New Republic]]''. Morris writes that he is open to [[historical revisionism]] but that Segev's central argument about Israel's internal condition leading up to the war "is essentially false." He adds: "For Segev, Arab politics and Arab society have no bearing upon the proper understanding of the origins of the war. ... [H]is book points readers and scholars in no worthwhile direction. Its argument is not merely wrong; it also makes a small contribution of its own to the contemporary delegitimation of Israel."<ref>[http://spme.org/spme-research/letters-from-our-readers/book-reviews-benny-morris-reviews-tom-segev-and-foxbats-over-dimona-for-new-republic/3552/ Book Reviews: Benny Morris Reviews Tom Segev and Foxbats Over Dimona for New Republic]</ref>
==Published works== * ''1949: The First Israelis'' (Hebrew: 1984, {{ISBN|965-261-040-2}}; English: 1998, {{ISBN|0-8050-5896-6}}) * ''Soldiers of Evil: The Commandants of the Nazi Concentration Camps'' (1988, {{ISBN|0-07-056058-7}}) * ''One Palestine, Complete: Jews and Arabs Under the British Mandate'' (2000, {{ISBN|0-316-64859-0}}) * ''The Seventh Million: Israelis and the Holocaust'' (2000, {{ISBN|0-8050-6660-8}}) * ''Elvis in Jerusalem: Post-Zionism and the Americanization of Israel'' (2003, {{ISBN|0-8050-7288-8}}) * ''Israel in 1967. And the land changed its visage'' (Hebrew: 2005, {{ISBN|965-07-1370-0}}) * ''1967: Israel, the War, and the Year That Transformed the Middle East'', Metropolitan Books (2006) * ''Simon Wiesenthal: The Life and Legends'', [[Jonathan Cape]] (2010) * ''A State at all Costs - The Story of David Ben-Gurion'' (Hebrew and German) 2018

{{About|the Australian sportsman|other people with the same name|Thomas Wills (disambiguation)}} {{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Tom Wills | image = Tom Wills 1857.jpg | caption = Wills, {{circa}} 1857 | birth_name = Thomas Wentworth Wills | birth_date = {{birth date|1835|8|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Molonglo Plain]], [[New South Wales]], Australia | death_date = {{death date and age|1880|5|2|1835|8|19|df=y}} | death_place = [[Heidelberg, Victoria|Heidelberg]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia | resting_place = Warringal Cemetery, Victoria, Australia | death_cause = [[Stab wound]] (suicide) | partner = Sarah Barbor | parents = [[Horatio Wills]]
Elizabeth McGuire | relatives = [[Thomas Antill]] (cousin)
[[H. C. A. Harrison]] (cousin) }} '''Thomas Wentworth Wills''' (19 August 1835 – 2 May 1880) was a sportsman who is credited with being Australia's first [[cricket]]er of significance and a founder of [[Australian rules football|Australian football]]. Born in the British colony of [[New South Wales]] to a wealthy family descended from [[convicts in Australia|convict]]s, Wills grew up in [[Australian bush|the bush]] on properties owned by his father, the pastoralist and politician [[Horatio Wills]], in what is now the Australian state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]. He befriended local [[Indigenous Australians|Aborigines]], learning their language and customs. At the age of 14, Wills went to England to attend [[Rugby School]], where he became [[captain (cricket)|captain]] of its cricket team, and played an early version of [[rugby football]]. After Rugby, Wills represented the [[Cambridge University Cricket Club]] in the [[The University Match (cricket)|annual match]] against [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford]], and played at [[first-class cricket|first-class]] level for [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]] and the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]]. An athletic [[all-rounder]] with exceptional [[bowling (cricket)|bowling]] skills, he was regarded as one of the finest young cricketers in England. Returning to Victoria in 1856, Wills achieved Australia-wide stardom as a cricketer, captaining the [[Victoria cricket team|Victorian team]] to repeated victories in [[List of Australian intercolonial cricket matches|intercolonial matches]]. He played for, and was secretary of the [[Melbourne Cricket Club]], but his [[larrikin]] streak and defections to rival clubs strained their relationship. In 1858 he called for the formation of a "foot-ball club" with a "code of laws" to keep cricketers fit during winter. After founding the [[Melbourne Football Club]] in 1859, Wills co-wrote the first [[laws of Australian football]]. He and his cousin [[H. C. A. Harrison]] spearheaded the sport's development as captains, umpires and administrators. In 1861, at the height of his fame, Wills joined his father on an eight-month trek into the [[Queensland]] [[outback]] to establish a family property. Two weeks after their arrival, Wills' father and 18 others were murdered in the [[Cullin-la-ringo massacre|largest massacre]] of settlers by Aborigines in Australian history. Wills survived and resumed playing sport upon his return to Victoria in 1864, and in 1866–67, led an [[Australian Aboriginal cricket team in England in 1868#Background|Aboriginal cricket team]] on an Australian tour as its captain-coach. In a career marked by controversy, Wills challenged cricket's [[amateur status in first-class cricket|amateur]]-[[professional sports|professional]] divide, and was frequently accused of [[gamesmanship|bending sporting rules]], sometimes to the point of [[cheating]]. An admitted "[[throwing (cricket)|chucker]]", Wills was [[no-ball]]ed out of major cricket in 1872. He failed in an 1876 comeback attempt, by which time he was considered a relic of a bygone era.{{sfn|de Moore|2005|p=371}} His remaining years were characterised by social alienation, flights from creditors, and heavy drinking, likely as a means of coping with [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD) symptoms that plagued him after the massacre. In 1880, suffering from [[delirium tremens]], Wills committed suicide by stabbing himself in the heart. Australia's first sporting celebrity, Wills fell into obscurity after his death, but has undergone a revival in [[culture of Australia|Australian culture]] since the 1990s. Today he is described as an archetypal tragic sports hero and as a symbol of [[reconciliation (ethnic relations)|reconciliation]] between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. Controversy surrounds a theory that Wills incorporated features of an [[Marn Grook|Aboriginal game]] into early Australian football. According to biographer Greg de Moore, Wills "stands alone in all his absurdity, his cracked egalitarian heroism and his fatal self-destructiveness—the finest cricketer and footballer of the age".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=326}} ==Family and early years== [[File:William Charles Wentworth, by Thomas Woolner (1825-1892).tif|thumb|upright|Wills' middle name comes from [[William Wentworth]], the statesman, explorer and "fighter for the rights of the Australian born". He served as Wills' childhood role model.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=8}}]] Wills was born on 19 August 1835 on the [[Molonglo Plain]]{{Ref_label|A|a|none}} near modern-day [[Canberra]], in what was the British [[penal colony]] of [[New South Wales]], as the elder child{{Ref_label|B|b|none}} of [[Horatio Wills|Horatio]] and Elizabeth (née McGuire) Wills.{{sfn|Mandle|1976}} Tom was a third-generation Australian of [[Convicts in Australia|convict]] descent: his mother was born to convicts from Ireland, and his paternal grandfather was Edward Wills, an English [[highwayman]] whose death sentence for armed robbery was commuted to [[penal transportation#Australia|transportation]], arriving in [[Botany Bay]] aboard the "hell ship" {{ship||Hillsborough|1783 EIC ship|2}} in 1799.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1p=3, 6|2a1=Howard|2a2=Larkins|2y=1981|2p=38}} Granted a conditional pardon in 1803, Edward became rich through mercantile activity in [[Sydney]] with his free wife Sarah (née Harding).{{sfn|Wills Cooke|2012|p=6}} He died in 1811, five months before Horatio's birth, and Sarah remarried to convict [[George Howe (printer)|George Howe]], owner of Australia's first newspaper, ''[[The Sydney Gazette]]''.{{sfn|Wills Cooke|2012|p=13}} Mainly self-educated, Horatio worked in the ''Gazette'' office from a young age, rising to become editor in 1832, the same year he met Elizabeth, an orphan from [[Parramatta]]. They married in December 1833.{{sfn|Wills Cooke|2012|pp=108–109}} Seventeen months after his birth, Tom was baptised Thomas Wentworth Wills in [[St Andrew's Cathedral, Sydney|St Andrew's]], Sydney, after statesman [[William Wentworth]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=8}} Drawing on Wentworth's pro-[[Currency (lads and lasses)|currency]] writings and the [[emancipist]] cause, Horatio, in his [[Australian nationalism|nationalist]] journal ''The Currency Lad'' (1832–33), made the first call for an [[republicanism in Australia|Australian republic]].{{sfn|McKenna|1996|pp=23–25}} [[File:Mount William as Seen from Mount Dryden.jpg|left|thumb|Wills grew up amongst Aboriginal clans in the Mount William area of the Grampians, shown in this 19th-century painting by [[Eugene von Guérard]].]] Horatio turned to pastoralism in the mid-1830s and moved with his family to the sheep run Burra Burra on the [[Molonglo River]].{{sfnm|1a1=Judd|1y=2007|1p=114|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=8}} Although athletic from an early age, Tom was prone to illness, and at one stage in 1839 his parents "almost despaired of his recovery".{{sfnm|1a1=Wills Cooke|1y=2012|1p=173|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=8–9}} The following year, in light of explorer [[Thomas Mitchell (explorer)|Thomas Mitchell]]'s discovery of "[[Australia Felix]]", the Willses, with shepherds and their families, were among the first settlers of the [[Grampian Mountains (Australia)|Grampians]] in the colony's [[Port Phillip District]] (now the state of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]). After [[squatting (pastoral)|squatting]] on [[Mount William (Mount Duwil)|Mount William]], they moved a few miles north through the foothills of [[Ararat, Victoria|Mount Ararat]], named so by Horatio because "like [[Noah's Ark|the Ark]], we rested there".{{sfnm|1a1=Molony|1y=2000|1pp=137–139|2a1=Wills Cooke|2y=2012|2p=37}} Horatio went through a period of intense religiosity while in the Grampians; at times his diary descends into incantation, "perhaps even madness" according to one scholar.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=190|2a1=Judd|2y=2007|2pp=115–116}} He implored himself and Tom to base their lives upon the [[New Testament]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=15}} Living under canvas, the Wills family took up the leases of a large property named Lexington (near present-day [[Moyston, Victoria|Moyston]]) in an area used by [[Djab wurrung]] Aboriginal clans as a meeting place.{{sfnm|1a1=Wills Cooke|1y=2012|1p=37, 53|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=10}} According to family members, Tom, as an only child, "was thrown much into the companionship of aborigines".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=165}} In an account of [[corroboree]]s from childhood, his cousin [[H. C. A. Harrison]]{{Ref_label|C|c|none}} remembered Tom's ability to learn Aboriginal songs, mimic their voice and gestures, and "speak their language as fluently as they did themselves, much to their delight."{{sfn|Hibbins|Mancini|1987|p=79}} It is speculated that Tom may have also [[Tom Wills#Marngrook theory|played Aboriginal sports]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=322–323}} Horatio wrote fondly of his son's kinship with Aborigines, and allowed local clans to live and hunt on Lexington.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1pp=331–332|2a1=Wills Cooke|2y=2012|2pp=37–39}} However, [[George Augustus Robinson]], the district's [[Chief Protector of Aborigines]], implicated Horatio and other local settlers in the murder of Aborigines. Horatio blamed "distant predatory tribes" for provoking hostilities in the area, and the closest he came to admitting that he had killed Aborigines was in a letter to Governor [[Charles La Trobe]]: "... we shall be compelled in self defence to measures that may involve us in unpleasant consequences".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=11–14}} Tom's first sibling, Emily, was born on Christmas Day 1842.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=14}} In 1846 Wills began attendance at William Brickwood's School in [[Melbourne]]. There he was looked after by Horatio's brother Thomas (Tom's namesake{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=8}}), a [[Victoria (Australia)#Creation of separate colony of Victoria|Victorian separatist]] and son-in-law of the Wills family's partner in the shipping trade, convict [[Mary Reibey]].{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1pp=15–16|2a1=Judd|2y=2007|2p=111}} Tom played in his first [[cricket]] matches at school, and he came in contact with the [[Melbourne Cricket Club]] through Brickwood, the club's vice-president.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=16}} By 1849, the year Wills' schooling in Melbourne ended, his family had grown to include brothers Cedric, Horace and Egbert.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=18}} Horatio had ambitious plans for the education of his children, especially Tom:{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=15}} {{quote|I now deeply vainly deplore my want of a mathematical and classical education. Vain regret! ... But my son! May he prove worthy of my experience! May I be spared for him—that he may be useful to his country—I never knew a father's care.}} ==England== ===Rugby School=== {{multiple image | align = left | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 = Tom Wills daguerreotype.jpg | width1 = 100 | alt1 = | caption1 = [[Daguerreotype]] of Wills, dating from his school years | image2 = Rugby school 1859.jpg | width2 = 200 | alt2 = | caption2 =Football at Rugby School, 1850s. Wills was singled out in the national press for his prowess on the field. }} Wills' father sent him to England in February 1850, aged fourteen, to attend [[Rugby School]], the most prestigious school in the country.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=18–19}} He arrived in London after a five-month sea voyage. There, during school holidays, he stayed with his paternal aunt Sarah, who moved from Sydney after the death of her first husband, convict [[William Redfern]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=18–19}} In his scheme for his children, Horatio wanted Tom to go on to study law at the [[University of Cambridge]], and return to Australia as a "professional man of eminence".{{sfn |de Moore|2011|p=52}} The reforms enacted by [[Thomas Arnold]], famed headmaster, made Rugby the crucible of [[muscular Christianity]], a "cult of athleticism" into which Wills was inculcated.{{sfn|Judd|2007|pp=133–135}} Wills took up cricket within a week of entering [[Rugby School#Houses|Evans House]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=23}} At first he bowled [[underarm bowling|underhand]], but it was considered outdated, so he tried [[roundarm bowling]]. He [[clean bowled]] a [[batting (cricket)|batsman]] with his first ball using this style and declared: "I felt I was a bowler."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=24}} Wills soon topped all of his house's [[cricket statistics]].{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=43}} At bat he was a "punisher" with a sound defence; however, in an era when stylish stroke-play was expected of a gentleman cricketer, he was said to have no style at all.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=40, 44|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=49}} In April 1852, aged sixteen, Wills joined the Rugby School XI, and on his debut at [[Lord's]] a few months later, against the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (MCC), he took a match-high 12 [[Wickets#Dismissing a batsman|wickets]].{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=37}} That year his bowling was vital in establishing Rugby as the greatest public school in English cricket.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=37}} In a prelude to his colonial career, critics stated that Wills ought to be [[no-ball]]ed for [[throwing (cricket)|throwing]]—an illegal [[bowling action]]. Rugby coach [[John Lillywhite]], the umpire who [[Edgar Willsher#Overarm bowling|famously no-balled]] professional [[Edgar Willsher]], defended his protégé. Wills survived the scandal.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1pp=38–39, 78–79|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=32–33}} He played with, and attracted praise from the leading cricketers of the age, including [[Alfred Mynn]]. [[William Clarke (cricketer)|William Clarke]], his hero, invited him to join the [[William Clarke's All-England Eleven|All-England Eleven]] in 1854, but he remained at school. The next year, he became Rugby XI [[captain (cricket)|captain]].{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=43|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=32, 47}} {{Quote box |width = 30em |bgcolor = #F9F9F9 |align = right |quote = "I know that if I [study] too hard I will become quite ill. We hardly get any play during school time." |source = {{mdash}} Wills to his father in an 1851 letter the size of a [[broadsheet]], the majority of which he devotes to his school cricket scores.{{sfnm|1a1=Wills Cooke|1y=2012|1pp=174–176|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=331}} }} Rugby, like other English public schools, had evolved [[English public school football games#Rugby football|its own variant of football]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=43}} The game in Wills' era—a rough and highly defensive struggle involving hundreds of boys—was confined to a competition amongst the houses.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=45|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=44–45}} Spanning his school years, Wills is one of the few players who is named in the newspapers' brief match reports.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=48}} His creative play and "eel-like agility" baffled the opposition, and his penchant for theatrics endeared him to the crowds.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=49}} One journalist noted his use of "slimy tricks", a possible early reference to his [[gamesmanship]].{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=49}} As a "dodger" in the forward line, he was a long and accurate shot at goal and served as his house's [[placekicker|kicker]].{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=50|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=46}} Wills also shone in the school's annual athletics carnival and his long-distance running ability in [[Paper Chase (game)|Hare and Hounds]] was unparalleled.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=51–55}} Wills cut a dashing figure with "impossibly wavy" hair and blue, almond-shaped eyes that "[burnt] with a pale light".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=50, 57}} By age 16 at 5'8" he was already taller than his father.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=28}} In ''[[The Guide to Cricketers|Lillywhite's Guide]]'' a few years later he measured in at 5'10" and it was written that "few athletes can boast of a more muscular and well-developed frame".{{Cite wikisource| title = Mr Thomas W. Wills: A Biographical Sketch | last = Hammersley | first = William| year = 1869}} Consumed by sport, Wills, to his father's chagrin, fell behind academically.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=40–42, 47–48}} It was said that he "could not bring himself to study for professional work" after "having led a sort of nomadic life when a youth in Australia".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=334}} Suffering from homesickness, he decorated his study with objects to remind him of Lexington, including [[Australian Aboriginal artifacts|Aboriginal weapons]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=25}} Horatio wrote to Tom about the latter's friends, the Djab wurrung: "They told me to send you up to them as soon as you came back."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=33}} ===Libertine cricketer=== {{Infobox cricketer | image = | country = Australia | batting = Right-handed | bowling = Right-arm medium | role = [[All-rounder]] | club1 = Gentlemen of Kent | year1 = 1854 | club2 = Gentlemen of Kent and Surrey | year2 = 1855 | club3 = [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] | year3 = 1855–56 | club4 = [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]] | year4 = 1855–56 | club5 = Kent and Sussex | year5 = 1856 | club6 = Gentlemen of Kent and Sussex | year6 = 1856 | club7 = [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]] | year7 = 1856 | club8 = [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] | year8 = 1856–76 | club9 = [[George Anderson (cricketer)|G. Anderson's XI]] | year9 = 1864 | umpire = true | fcumpired = 1 (1871) | columns = 1 | column1 = [[First-class cricket|First-class]] | matches1 = 32 | runs1 = 602 | bat avg1 = 12.28 | 100s/50s1 = 0/1 | top score1 = 58 | deliveries1 = 3731 | wickets1 = 130 | bowl avg1 = 10.09 | fivefor1 = 15 | tenfor1 = 3 | best bowling1 = 7/44 | catches/stumpings1 = 20/– | date = 24 April | year = 2012 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/16/16872/16872.html CricketArchive }} In June 1855, nearing his 20th birthday, Wills finished his schooling. Hailed as Rugby's exemplar sportsman, his status as a cricketer had come to define him in the eyes of others.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=44}} In a farewell tribute from his fellow students he was called simply "the school bowler".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=50}} After leaving Rugby, and with a steady supply of money from his father, Wills roamed Britain in pursuit of cricketing pleasure. Regarded as "one of the most promising cricketers in the kingdom",{{sfn|Inglis|1993|p=127}} he played with royalty, made [[first-class cricket|first-class]] appearances for the MCC, [[Kent County Cricket Club|Kent]], and various [[Gentlemen cricket team|Gentlemen sides]], and also fell in with the [[I Zingari]]—the "gypsy lords of English cricket"—an amateur club known for its exotic costumes and hedonistic lifestyle.{{sfnm|1a1=Flanagan|1y=2008|1p=546|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=51–52, 57}} Against Horatio's wishes, Tom, having failed to [[matriculate]], did not continue his studies at Cambridge, but did play cricket for the [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|university's team]] (as well as [[Magdalene College]]), most notably in 1856 when rules barring non-student players from the [[The University Match (cricket)|University Match]] were ignored, Cambridge being "one man short" against [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=52–53, 334}} In June, Wills played cricket at Rugby School for the last time, representing the MCC alongside [[Heneage Finch, 6th Earl of Aylesford|Lord Guernsey]], the [[Edward Turnour, 5th Earl Winterton|Earl of Winterton]], and [[Charles du Cane]], governor-to-be of [[Tasmania]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=51}} Following a month of cricket in Ireland, Wills, at the behest of Horatio, returned to England to prepare for his journey home to Australia.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=53}} The last eighteen months had exposed Wills to "the richest sporting experience on earth".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=32}} His six years in England charted a way of life—one of drinking, reckless spending and playing games—that he would continue to lead until his death.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=32}} ==Colonial hero== Wills returned to Australia aboard the ''Oneida'' steamship, arriving in Melbourne on 23 December 1856. The minor port city of his youth had risen to world renown as the booming financial centre of the [[Victorian gold rush]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=54}} Horatio, now a member of the [[Victorian Legislative Assembly|Legislative Assembly]] in the [[Parliament of Victoria|Victorian Parliament]], was living on "Belle Vue", a farm at [[Moolap, Victoria#Point Henry|Point Henry]] near [[Geelong]], the Wills' family home since 1853.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=55–57}} In his first summer back in Melbourne, Wills stayed with his extended family, the Harrisons, at their home on [[Victoria Parade, Melbourne|Victoria Parade]], and entered a [[Collins Street, Melbourne|Collins Street]] law firm to appease his father, but he seems never to have practiced; the few comments he made about law suggest it meant little to him.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=64, 113}} "Tom was no dunce", writes Greg de Moore. He was "negotiating a path to greatness."{{sfn|de Moore|2012|p=16}} The Australian colonies were described as "cricket mad" in the 1850s, and Victorians, in particular, were said to live "in an atmosphere of cricket".{{sfnm|1a1=Mandle|1y=1973|1p=225|2a1=Hibbins|2y=2013|2pp=110–111}} [[Intercolonial cricket in Australia|Intercolonial contests]], first held in 1851, provided an outlet for the at times intense rivalry between Victoria and New South Wales. With his reputation preceding him, Wills became the bearer of Victoria's hopes of winning its first match against the elder colony.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=57–58}} A former acquaintance in England, [[William Hammersley]], then captain of the [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria XI]], recalled Wills' first appearance on the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) for a trial match, staged one week after his return: {{quote|... the observed of all observers, with his Zingari stripe and somewhat flashy get up, fresh from Rugby and college, with the polish of the old country upon him. He was then a model of muscular Christianity.}} Wills won the match for his side with a top score of 57 [[not out]],{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=57–58}} and ''[[The Age]]'' said of his playing style and entertaining ability that "there has not been a more amusing scene on this ground".[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/154821778 "Eleven of Victoria v. A Selected Eleven"]. ''The Age'' (Melbourne). 6 January 1857. p. 3. Retrieved 6 January 2015. In the January 1857 intercolonial against New South Wales, held on [[the Domain, Sydney|the Domain]] in Sydney, Wills was the leading wicket-taker with ten victims, but failed with the bat. Bowling fast round-arm, the Victorians scoffed at the "antiquated" underhand action of their opponents. The latter style proved effective, however, giving New South Wales a 65-run win.{{sfnm|1a1=Clowes|1y=2007|1pp=6–7|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=60}} Back in Victoria, Wills joined numerous clubs, including the provincial Corio Cricket Club, based in Geelong, and the elite [[Melbourne Cricket Club]] (MCC).{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=62}} Although he had a greater affinity for Corio, the MCC maintained that Wills belonged to them, and took offence at his lack of loyalty to any one club.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=62, 95}} In order to secure Wills in matches between the two teams, the MCC allowed Corio to field an extra five men to make up for his loss.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=222–223}} [[File:Intercolonial Cricket Match Victoria New South Wales 1858.jpg|thumb|left|Wills is shown preparing to bowl in an intercolonial match between Victoria and New South Wales, MCG, 1858. He captained Victoria to its first victory and was "an instant colonial hero".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=365}}]] Parliament and business came to a standstill in Melbourne for the January 1858 intercolonial match between Victoria and New South Wales, held at the MCG. Captaining Victoria, Wills took 8 wickets, the most of his side, and on the second day, batting in the [[middle order]], a ball hit an imperfection in the pitch and knocked him unconscious. He recovered, played on for two hours, and won the match at day's end with a top score of 49*.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=78–80}} The crowd rushed the field and chaired Wills off in triumph, and victory celebrations lasted for several days throughout the colony.{{sfnm|1a1=Judd|1y=2007|1pp=141–142|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=80–81}} Now a household name and the darling of Melbourne's elite, Wills was proclaimed "the greatest cricketer in the land".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=85–86}} Although Wills enjoyed his lofty amateur status, he liked to socialise with and support working class professional cricketers—an [[egalitarian]] attitude that sometimes led to conflict with sporting officialdom but endeared him to the common man.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=72–76}} Wills' allegiance to professionals was highlighted by an incident in Tasmania in February 1858 when the [[Launceston Cricket Club]] shunned professional members of his touring Victorian side. Infuriated, he spoke out against being "forsaken" in a "strange land". One week later, during a game in [[Hobart]], Wills earned the locals' ire as he "[jumped] about exultantly" after maiming a Tasmanian batsman with a spell of hostile fast bowling.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=83–84}} Wills was elected secretary of the MCC during the 1857–58 season.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=72}} It was a role in which he proved to be chaotic and disorganised. MCC delegates took issue with Wills' "continued non-attendance" at meetings, and when the club fell into debt, his poor administrative skills were blamed.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=86}} He acted on year-long threats in mid-1858 and deserted the MCC, leaving its records and amenities in dissaray; to this day, the only minutes that cannot be found date from his secretaryship.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=92}} A lasting tension existed between Wills and the MCC's inner circle. According to [[Martin Flanagan (journalist)|Martin Flanagan]], "It was a relationship which couldn't last as Wills only knew one way—his own."{{sfn|Judd|2007|p=152, 335}} ==Football pioneer== {{further|Origins of Australian rules football}} {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header_align = center | header = | image1 = Australianfootball1866.jpg | width1 = 192 | alt1 = | caption1 = Football in the [[Yarra Park|Richmond Paddock]], 1860s. The field's hard playing surface influenced Wills' codification of the game.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=94}} | image2 = HCA Colden Harrison.jpg | width2 = 108 | alt2 = | caption2 = Wills' cousin [[H. C. A. Harrison]] joined him in pioneering football in 1859. }} Wills was a compulsive writer to the press on cricketing matters and in the late 1850s his letters sometimes appeared on a daily basis.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=77–78}} An agitator like his father, he used language "in the manner of a speaker declaiming forcefully from a platform".{{sfnm|1a1=Blainey|1y=2003|1p=8|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=119}} On 10 July 1858, the Melbourne-based ''[[Bell's Life in Victoria and Sporting Chronicle]]'' published [[s:Winter Practice|a letter]] by Wills that is regarded as a catalyst for a new style of football, known today as [[Australian rules football]].{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=2–3}} Titled "Winter Practice", it begins:''[[Bell's Life in Victoria]]'', 10 July 1858. {{quote|Now that cricket has been put aside for some few months to come, and cricketers have assumed somewhat of the chrysalis nature (for a time only 'tis true), but at length will again burst forth in all their varied hues, rather than allow this state of torpor to creep over them, and stifle their new supple limbs, why can they not, I say, form a foot-ball club, and form a committee of three or more to draw up a code of laws?}} In endeavouring to keep cricketers active during the off-season, Wills made the first public declaration of its kind in Australia: that football should be a regular and organised activity.{{sfnm|1a1=Hess|1y=2008|1p=8|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=87}} Around this time he helped to foster football in Melbourne's schools.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=91}} The local headmasters, his collaborators, were inspired in large part by [[Thomas Hughes]]' novel ''[[Tom Brown's School Days]]'' (1857), an account of life at Rugby School under the headship of Thomas Arnold.{{sfn|Blainey|2003|pp=28–30, 207}} Due to similarities between their sporting careers at Rugby, Wills has been called the "real-life embodiment" of [[Tom Brown (character)|Tom Brown]], the novel's fictitious hero.{{sfn|Judd|2007|p=135}} Wills' letter was alluded to two weeks after its publication in an advertisement posted by his friend, professional cricketer and publican [[James Bryant (Australian cricketer)|Jerry Bryant]], for a "[[scratch match]]" held adjacent to the MCG at the [[Yarra Park|Richmond Paddock]]. The first of several kickabouts held that year involving Wills, Bryant and other Melbourne cricketers,{{sfnm|1a1=Hess|1y=2008|1p=8, 10|2a1=Pennings|2y=2011|2p=14}} it was described by one participant as "football [[wikt:Babel|Babel]]"; a "short code of rules" were to be drawn up afterwards, however this does not seem to have occurred.{{sfnm|1a1=Blainey|1y=2003|1p=22|2a1=Coventry|2y=2015|2p=9}} Another landmark game, played without fixed rules over three Saturdays and co-umpired by Wills and teacher [[John Macadam]], began on the same site on 7 August between forty [[Scotch College, Melbourne|Scotch College]] students and a like number from [[Melbourne Grammar]].{{sfn|Blainey|2003|pp=15–18}} The two schools have since [[Cordner–Eggleston Cup|competed annually]].{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|2009|p=9}} Wills emerged as the standout figure in accounts of Melbourne football in 1858.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=91}} These early experimental games were more rugby-like than anything else—low-scoring, low-to-the-ground "gladiatorial" tussles.{{sfnm|1a1=Hibbins|1a2=Ruddell|1y=2009|1p=13|2a1=Pennings|2y=2013|2p=1}} The last recorded match of the year is the subject of the first known Australian football poem, published in ''[[Melbourne Punch|Punch]]''. Wills, the only player named, is reified as "the Melbourne chief", leading his men to victory against a side from [[South Yarra]].{{sfnm|1a1=Hess|1y=2008|1p=16|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=91–92}} Following a scratch match at the start of the 1859 football season, the [[Melbourne Football Club]] officially came into being on 14 May.{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|p=5}} Three days later, Wills and three other members—Hammersley, journalist [[J. B. Thompson]] and teacher [[Thomas H. Smith]]—met near the MCG at the Parade Hotel, owned by Bryant, to devise and codify the club's rules.{{sfn|Hess|2008|p=i}} The men went over the rules of four English schools; Hammersley recalled Wills' preference for the Rugby game, but it was found to be confusing and too violent.{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|p=7}} Subsequently, they rejected common features such as "hacking" (shin-kicking) and produced a signed document listing [[Laws of Australian rules football#Melbourne Rules of 1859|ten simple rules]] suited to grown men and Australian conditions.{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|pp=14–15}} Heading the list of signatories, Wills, too, saw the need for compromise.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=101, 325}} He wrote to his brother Horace: "Rugby was not a game for us, we wanted a winter pastime but men could be harmed if thrown on the ground so we thought differently."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=101}} Thompson and Hammersley's promotion of the new code, together with Wills' star power, encouraged the spread of football throughout Victoria. ==Height of celebrity== [[File:Tom Wills Victorian cricketers 1859.jpg|thumb|Wills (far right) with professional members of the Victoria XI, 1859. He preferred the company of professionals in an era when they were shunned by amateurs of his social stature.]] After his fallout with the MCC, Wills moved freely about Victoria, playing for any club of his choosing. He became president of [[Collingwood Cricket Club|Collingwood]] and vice-president of [[Monash Tigers|Richmond]], raising the standard of the latter's play to make it the premier club in the colony.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=95–96}} There were calls to bar Wills from some club matches, for when a side secured him, often as a late inclusion, he was seen to distort the balance of play and dramatically alter the odds, forcing bookmakers to declare "[[wikt:all bets are off|all bets are off]]". But all clubs still coveted Wills when it suited their cause, and there was scarcely a day when he was not playing or practising cricket.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=62, 77}} Wills was reappointed captain of Victoria for the January 1859 intercolonial against New South Wales, held at the Domain. He broke his right middle finger on day one while attempting a catch. Undeterred, Wills top scored in the first innings with 15* and took 5/24 and 6/25, carrying Victoria to an upset win.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=96–97}} He resigned from the intercolonial match committee in protest of Thompson assailing him for not practicing ahead of the next match against New South Wales. During a follow-up practice match, players struggled in the day's heat, and ignoring calls to retire, Wills suffered a near-fatal [[sunstroke]]. Hammersley wrote that Wills felt obliged to perform for the large crowd that had gathered to watch him.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=106–107}} Over 25,000 people attended the MCG in February 1860 to see Victoria, captained by Wills, play New South Wales. Wills bowled unchanged in both innings, taking 6/23 and 3/16, and top scored with 20*. Victoria won by 69 runs.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=107}} The Melbourne media gave Wills the sobriquet "Great Gun of the Colony".{{sfn|Judd|2007|p=142}} A British correspondent called him "a cricketer born"."Cricket in the South". ''The Australian Mail''. 14 May 1861. p. 1. The Sydney press, championing Wills as a native New South Welshman, agreed:[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28630794 "Grand National Cricket Match"]. ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' (Sydney). 27 January 1859. p. 12. Retrieved 7 August 2015. {{quote|Tall, muscular, and slender, Mr. Wills seems moulded by nature to excel in every branch of the noble game, ... on the field we find him the admiration of the ground, while in the combination of his successes, [his teammates] recognise with pride the still more arduous duties of an unwearied and most discreet captain.}} {{Quote box |width = 30em |bgcolor = #F9F9F9 |align = left |quote = "I think the ground should be free to all, so that the captain of each side could dispose of his forces in any position he likes; and when this is done, and the ball is carried on from one end of the ground to the other, by a succession of good, well-directed kicks, to the hands of those that the ball was intended for, ... it has a very pretty effect, and is the result of some skill." |source = {{mdash}} Wills on how football should be played{{sfn|Coventry|2015|p=12}} }} Wills remained an influential figure in Australian football from 1859 to 1860.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=104}} While he fought for the adoption of several Rugby School customs—such as a [[free kick (Australian rules football)|free kick]] for [[mark (Australian rules football)|marking]], the use of an [[Rugby union ball|oval-shaped ball]], and (unsuccessfully) a crossbar—he pushed the game in new directions as a captain and tactician, such as during an 1860 match when he used positional play to exploit the code's lack of an [[offside (sport)|offside law]], at which point, according to [[James Coventry]], "the full potential of the sport started to be realised".{{sfn|Coventry|2015|p=10}} At Wills' invitation, his cousin H. C. A. Harrison took up football in 1859, and quickly became a leading player and captain.{{sfn|Coventry|2015|p=27, 30}} He looked up to Wills, terming him "the beau-ideal of an athlete"—high praise given that Harrison was the champion runner of Victoria.{{sfnm|1a1=Blainey|1y=2003|1pp=68–69|2a1=De Moore|2y=2011|2p=105}} Their presence in Geelong fuelled a local craze for football and ensured the [[Geelong Football Club]]'s supremacy in the early 1860s.{{sfn|Pennings|2012|p=29–31}} In an era when players moved freely among clubs, Wills still represented Melbourne, and in 1860, was the first captain and secretary of the Richmond Football Club (no connection with [[Richmond Football Club|the AFL club]]).{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|2009|p=8, 12}} The code underwent revisions around this time, principally in response to the on-field actions of dominant players. "And there were none more dominant than Wills and Harrison", writes Coventry.{{sfnm|1a1=Coventry|1y=2015|1pp=29–30|2a1=Hibbins|2a2=Ruddell|2y=2009|2pp=16–18}} ==Queensland== [[File:Horatio Wills portrait.jpg|thumb|upright|Horatio Wills]] With plans underway for the [[English cricket team in Australia in 1861–62|first tour of Australia]] by an [[England national cricket team|English cricket team]], Wills announced his retirement from sport. At his father's beckoning, Wills agreed to leave Victoria to help found a new family property, Cullin-la-ringo, on the [[Nogoa River]] in [[outback]] [[Queensland]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=111–112}} He prepared for six months in country Victoria where learnt the crafts of a [[squatter (pastoral)|squatter]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=115}} In his will, Horatio—showing a "deep understanding" of Tom's personality—wrote that his son would be removed from the station and receive a diminished inheritance in the event of "misconducting himself" as manager.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=114–115}} In January 1861, Tom, Horatio and a party of employees and their families travelled by steamer to [[Brisbane]], disembarked in [[Moreton Bay]], and then, with livestock and supplies, set out on an eight-month trek through Queensland's rugged interior.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=115}} Food was scarce and Tom hunted native game to fend off starvation.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=116}} They suffered many other hardships and even death when, in [[Toowoomba]], one of Horatio's men drowned.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=116}} On the [[Darling Downs]] over 10,000 sheep were collected.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=117}} The size of the Wills party attracted the attention of local Aborigines, and the two groups engaged in games of mimicry.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=121}} Wary of entering [[Australian frontier wars#Queensland|the region's frontier war]], Horatio sought peaceful coexistence with the Aborigines.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=118}} The party reached Cullin-la-ringo, situated on Kairi Aboriginal land, in early October, and proceeded to set up camp.{{sfn|Reid|1981|pp=70–71}} ===Cullin-la-ringo massacre=== {{main|Cullin-la-ringo massacre}} [[File:Wills Tragedy 1861.jpg|thumb|left|''The Wills Tragedy, 1861'' depicts the aftermath of the deadliest attack on settlers by Aborigines in the [[Australian frontier wars]].]] On the afternoon of 17 October, two weeks after their arrival, Horatio and eighteen of his party were murdered in the [[Cullin-la-ringo massacre|deadliest massacre]] of settlers by Aborigines in Australian history.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=3|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=120–122}} Tom was away from the property at the time, having been sent with two [[stockman (Australia)|stockmen]] to collect supplies left en route to Cullin-la-Ringo. He returned several days later to a scene of devastation.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=121}} Despairing and in shock, Wills first wrote to Harrison in Melbourne: "... all our party except I have been slaughtered by the black's ... I am in a great fix no men."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=122}} Police, [[native police]] and vigilante groups from neighbouring stations swiftly tracked down and killed at least 30 local Aborigines; the total may have been 70.{{sfnm|1a1=Reid|1y=1981|1pp=74–75|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=130}} Wills took refuge near Cullin-la-ringo, and though he desired to avenge his father's death, there is no evidence that he joined the reprisal raids.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=125, 130}} Conflicting reports reached the outside world and for a time it was feared that Tom had died.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=126}} In the press, Horatio was accused of ignoring warnings and allowing Aborigines to encroach on his property.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=131}} The retribution was also called excessive.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=130, 341}} Tom vehemently defended his father against any perceived criticism.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=131}} Privately, in his letter to Harrison, he admitted, "if we had used common precaution all would have been well".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=134}} It was later revealed that, prior to leaving the camp, Tom advised Horatio to be watchful of the local Aborigines, but according to Hammersley, "the old man prided himself on being able to manage the blacks ... and said they would never harm him."{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=129–130, 133}} The Queensland press, still in the wake of the massacre, suggested that Wills, "now a Queenslander", be approached to captain [[Queensland cricket team|the colony's cricket team]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=128}} Different reasons were put forward at the time to account for the Wills tragedy.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=125}} For many colonists, it confirmed the popular belief that Aborigines were bloodthirsty [[wikt:savage|savage]]s.{{sfn|Reid|1981|p=79}} Tom never articulated his version of events in writing, but his brother Cedric wrote years later that it was an act of revenge for an attack made on local Aborigines by squatter Jesse Gregson. He quoted Tom as saying, "If the truth is ever known, you will find that it was through Gregson shooting those blacks; that was the cause of the murder."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=134}} In the years following the massacre, Wills experienced [[flashback (psychology)|flashback]]s, nightmares and an [[Da Costa's syndrome|irritable heart]]—features of what is now known as [[posttraumatic stress disorder]] (PTSD). Having immersed himself in the [[drinking culture]] of colonial sport, he increased his alcohol consumption in a likely attempt to blot out memories and alleviate sleep disturbance.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1pp=136–137|2a1=de Moore|2y=2008|2pp=214–217}} Wills' sister Emily wrote of him two months after the massacre: "He says he never felt so changed in the whole course of his life".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=136}} ===Riot and expulsion=== [[File:Tom Wills carte de visite.jpg|thumb|left|Tom Wills, c. 1863]] Wills made a vow over Horatio's grave to remain on Cullin-la-ringo and make it "the pride of Queensland"—words that, according to de Moore, "enshrined and imprisoned" Tom as the new head of the family.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=193|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=134–135}} Hypervigilant, he slept only three hours a night with a rifle beside his bed and watched for signs of another attack.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1p=137|2a1=de Moore|2y=2012|2p=17}} He began to rebuild the station pending the arrival of his uncle-in-law, William Roope, who took control of Cullin-la-ringo in December 1861, but soon left due to Wills acting "exceedingly ill" to him.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=141–142}} Wills struggled to cope with the harsh conditions and isolation of the outback. He went blind for weeks after contracting "[[sandy blight]]". He went to Sydney in January 1863 to captain Victoria against New South Wales on the Domain. The match turned into a riot when the crowd [[pitch invasion|invaded the field]] during a dispute over the Victorian umpire's impartiality. Wills, leading his men from the Domain, was struck in the face by a stone, and professionals [[George Marshall (Victoria cricketer)|George Marshall]] and [[William Greaves (cricketer)|William Greaves]] fled the city, reducing the Victorian side to nine men. Wills took 8 wickets and top scored in both innings (25* and 17*), but Victoria lost by 84 runs. The Melbourne media castigated Wills for allowing the game to continue and called him a traitor when evidence surfaced that he agreed to play for New South Wales in the weeks prior to the match. He denied all accusations and wrote in an angry letter to ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'': "I for one do not think that Victoria will ever send an Eleven up here again."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=149–151}} Back in Victoria, he became engaged to Julie Anderson, a farmer's daughter from [[Skipton, Victoria|Skipton]] and friend of the Wills family. Her name does not appear in any of Wills' surviving letters; he rarely mentioned the women he courted, let alone his feelings for them.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=153–155, 171}} Wills stayed in Geelong for the start of the 1863 football season, breaking his promise of an early return to Cullin-la-ringo, much to the dismay of his mother and the holding's trustees.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=155}} Wills finally returned to Queensland in May and was sworn in as a [[Justice of the Peace#Queensland|Justice of the Peace]] upon arrival in Brisbane.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=156}} Over the next few months at Cullin-la-ringo, he reported at least three murders of local settlers by Aborigines, among them one of his shepherds.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=134–135}} He accosted government officials, seeking the detachment of a Native Police Force to his station for protection, and scorned "Brisbane saints" for sympathising with the plight of Aborigines in the Nogoa region.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1pp=131–132|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=157–158}} With the cricket season approaching, Wills agreed to captain Queensland against New South Wales, and then left the colony to lead a Victoria XXII at the MCG against [[George Parr (cricketer)|George Parr]]'s [[English cricket team in Australia and New Zealand in 1863–64|All-England Eleven]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=159}} In awe of his 1,800 mile dash across the continent to play cricket, the English thought it a madman's journey.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=160}} Wills arrived on the final day of the match to a rapturous reception, and went in as a substitute fielder.[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/72512672 "Grand International Cricket Match"]. ''The Star'' (Ballarat). 6 January 1864. p. 2. Retrieved 25 January 2016. He then joined the visitors on their Victorian tour.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=161}} The 1863–64 season saw Wills' engagement to Anderson collapse, possibly due to his womanising, and the trustees of Cullin-la-ringo accused him of mismanaging the property, in part by squandering family finances on alcohol while claiming it as station expenditure.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=197, 222|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=162–163}} They demanded that he stay in Victoria to answer for the property's runaway debt. In response, Wills left Australia to join Parr's XI on a month-long tour of New Zealand.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=164}} Initially standing in as umpire, he went on to captain local teams against the English, and filled the same role for a Victoria XXII at the end of the tour in Melbourne.{{sfn|de Moore|p=165, 168}} He faced the trustees soon after. With his mother's reluctant approval, they decided to dismiss him from Cullin-la-ringo, thus fulfilling the premonition in Horatio's will.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=166–168}} ==Return to Victoria== [[File:Geelong Melbourne 1880.jpg|thumb|Football match between Geelong and Melbourne. The two clubs fought over which side "owned" Wills.]] Wills stayed at the family home in Geelong. Always a [[black sheep]] of sorts, he now became increasingly estranged from his mother and sister Emily.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=201|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=169–170}} Family letters from mid-1864 reveal that Wills had a "wife"—a "bad woman" according to Emily. It is likely a reference to the already-married Sarah Barbor (née Duff). Born in [[Dublin]], she is a mysterious figure, but is known to have remained Wills' lifelong partner. The [[De facto relationship|de facto]] nature of their relationship, and even Barbor's existence, were probably kept secret from Wills' mother for a number of years.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=171–172, 345–346}} Throughout the 1865 football season, Wills played for and often captained Melbourne and Geelong, two of the game's most powerful clubs. At the end of a winter beset with public brawls over which team "owned" him, Wills moved to Geelong for the remainder of his career, prompting ''Bell's Life in Victoria'' to report that Melbourne had lost "the finest leader of men on the football field".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=173, 176–177}} The following year, when the [[running bounce]] and [[Laws of australian football#Victorian Rules of 1866|other rules were formalised]] at a meeting of club delegates under Harrison's chairmanship, Wills was not present; his move to Geelong had cut him off from the rule-making process in Melbourne.{{sfnm|1a1=Hibbins|1a2=Ruddell|1y=2009|1p=22|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=181}} Intercolonials between Victoria and New South Wales resumed at the MCG on Boxing Day 1865, nearly three years since the Sydney riot. [[Sam Cosstick]], [[William Caffyn]] and other Victorian professionals defected to the rival colony due to pay disputes with the MCC. Wills, leading the weakened Victorian side to an against-the-odds win, took 6 wickets and contributed 58—the first [[half century]] in Australian first-class cricket—to 285, a record intercolonial total.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=178–180}} Allegations that Wills cheated his way to victory failed to endanger his status as a folk hero and "a source of eternal hope" for Victoria.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=85, 89|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=179–180}} ==Aboriginal cricket team== {{see also|Australian Aboriginal cricket team in England in 1868}} [[File:Aboriginal cricket team Tom Wills 1866.jpg|thumb|Wills (back row, center) with the Aboriginal XI outside the MCC pavilion of the MCG, December 1866]] In May 1866, the MCC's minute book featured an unusual request: Roland Newbury, the club's pavilion keeper, wanted "use of the ground for two days ... for purpose of a match with the native black eleven".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=136}} It was the first intimation of a cricket match between the MCC and an Aboriginal team from Victoria's [[Western District (Victoria)|Western District]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=181}} The motive behind the match, scheduled for late December, was a financial one, and in August, Wills agreed to coach the Aborigines. Wills' reasons for accepting the role remain a mystery, but his need for money was likely a factor.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=137}} This was to mark the beginning of his transition from amateur to professional sportsman.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=182–183}} Wills travelled inland in November to convene the players from [[Edenhope, Victoria|Edenhope]] and [[Harrow, Victoria|Harrow]], where they worked as [[station hand]]s.{{sfn|Mallett|2002|pp=18–20}} One of their employers, William Hayman, acted as the team's manager and "protector".{{sfn|Mallett|2002|pp=23–24}} They were mostly [[Jardwadjali]] men who shared common vocabulary with the neighbouring Djab wurrung people, which enabled Wills to use the Aboriginal language he learnt as a child.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=184}} From their training ground at [[Lake Wallace]], Wills, in a "tactical strike", boasted to the Melbourne press of the Aborigines' powers, especially the batsmanship of Unamurriman, commonly known as [[Johnny Mullagh|Mullagh]].{{Ref_label|D|d|none}} In a response that drew widespread criticism, the MCC strengthened its ranks with non-members.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1p=184|2a1=de Moore|2y=2008|2p=140}} Public sympathy was with the Aborigines when they arrived in Melbourne and over 10,000 spectators attended the MCG on Boxing Day to see them play.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article199053811 "M.C.C. vs. Ten Aboriginals with T. W. Wills"]. ''Bell's Life in Victoria and Sporting Chronicle'' (Melbourne). 29 December 1866. p. 2. Retrieved 25 January 2016. Captained by Wills, they lost the match, but won praise for their performance. Wills afterwards accused the MCC of "treachery".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=188–189}} It is unknown what Wills and the Aborigines made of the broader social and political dimensions of the enterprise.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=209}} Some of Wills' contemporaries were shocked that he would associate with Aborigines in the shadow of his father's death.{{sfn|de Moore|2012|p=17}} Others, such as this writer in ''[[Empire (newspaper)|The Empire]]'', addressed him as a hero:{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=198–199}} {{quote|Although you may not be fully aware of the fact, allow me to tell you that you have rendered a greater service to the aboriginal races of this country and to humanity, than any man who has hitherto attempted to uphold the title of the blacks to rank amongst men.}} [[File:Albert Ground Sydney.jpg|thumb|left|Wills' stint in jail following his arrest on the [[Albert Ground, Sydney|Albert Ground]] (pictured) marked the decline of his role within the team.]] While Melburnians were enthralled by the Aborigines, the annual intercolonial between Victoria and New South Wales—usually the season highlight—failed to excite public interest, and Victoria's loss in Sydney was put down to Wills' absence.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=190}} The Aboriginal team improved as it toured Victoria in January. After an easy win in Geelong, Wills took the players to "Belle Vue" to meet his mother.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=191}} Back in Melbourne, two of the Aborigines, [[Bullocky (cricketer)|Bullocky]] (Bullenchanach) and Cuzens (Yellana), joined Wills in representing Victoria against a Tasmanian XVI.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=199–200}} The team's successes provoked a public discourse over past mistreatment of Aborigines and future [[sociology of race and ethnic relations|relations between the races]].{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1pp=197–198|2a1=de Moore|2y=2008|2pp=146–147}} Wills' role took on a symbolic significance: his status as a 'native' (native-born Australian) was used to identify him with his '[[wikt:native#Noun|native]]' (indigenous) teammates, and he was also noted for speaking in "their own lingo".{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=152|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=185}} Jellico (Murrumgunarriman), the "team jester", joked: "[Wills] too much along of us. He speak nothing now but [[wikt:blackfellow|blackfellow]] talk."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=196–197}} They went to Sydney in February to begin a tour of the colonies and overseas.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=192, 200–201}} Aware of the tour's lucrative potential, Englishman [[Charles Lawrence (cricketer)|Charles Lawrence]], captain of New South Wales, invited the team to stay at his hotel on [[Manly Beach]].{{sfn|Mallett|2002|pp=26–27}} Their first match against his club at the [[Albert Ground, Sydney|Albert Ground]] in [[Redfern, New South Wales|Redfern]] came to a dramatic halt when Wills was arrested and briefly gaoled for a breach of contract.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=154–159}} He and W. E. B. Gurnett, the tour promoter, had been vying to take over as manager.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=348}} The team was left stranded after Gurnett embezzled some of the funds, confirming Wills' suspicion that he was a con artist.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=205}} With plans of a trip abroad abandoned, Lawrence set up a "benefit" match, and by the end of the tour's New South Wales leg, had usurped Wills as captain.{{sfnm|1a1=Mallett|1y=2002|1p=28|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=206}} No longer attracting significant crowds or media attention, they returned to Victoria in May, and within two weeks, Wills was in Geelong playing football.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=207}} It has been said that, due to his drinking habit, he exercised a "bad influence" upon the Aborigines, four of whom died from illness during or soon after the tour; the inquest into one death, that of Watty (Bilvayarrimin), and a follow-up police report revealed cases of alcohol abuse among the players.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1pp=240–241|2a1=Mallett|2y=2002|2pp=28–29}} The surviving members formed part of the Aboriginal team which Lawrence [[Australian Aboriginal cricket team in England in 1868|took to England in 1868]], ten years before the first [[Australia national cricket team|Australian XI]] classed as representative [[Australian cricket team in England and the United States in 1878|went overseas]].{{sfn|Mallett|2002|p=25, 29}} Wills resented Lawrence for reviving the team without him; his exclusion has been called the tragedy of his sporting career.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1p=214|2a1=Flanagan|2y=2008|2p=548}} ==Ambiguous professional== [[File:William Handcock Tom Wills.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Tom Wills portrait|Portrait of Wills]] in the colours of the MCC, William Handcock, 1870, [[National Sports Museum]] collection]] Without career prospects outside of sport, Wills joined the MCC as a professional at the start of the 1867–68 season; however, he was not openly referred to as such. Instead, the club devised the title of '[[tutor]]' in order that he maintain the prestige of his amateur background.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=210–212}} Played on the MCG, the December 1867 intercolonial between Victoria and New South Wales ended in a sound victory for the former, principally due to Wills' nine-wicket haul and [[Richard Wardill]]'s [[century (cricket)|century]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=214}} Wills had been Victoria's preferred captain for over a decade. Writing in his sports column, Hammersley claimed that, as a paid cricketer, Wills lacked "moral ascendancy" over amateurs.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=218–219}} When he lost the captaincy to Wardill, an amateur, on the eve of the March 1869 match against New South Wales, he refused to play under him, or, indeed, anyone else. The Victorians condemned Wills and resolved to go on without him, after which he retracted his decision not to play. This was the last intercolonial played on the Domain and Victoria recovered from Wardill's [[diamond duck]] to win by 78 runs. Wills scalped 7 wickets in a single innings.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=218–219}} After the intercolonial, Wills announced that he would not play for Victoria again, even if the colony wanted him.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=222}} He planned to return to Cullin-la-ringo in early 1869, but his mother, still "very dissatisfied" with him, requested that he stay away from the station.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=232}} The MCC took him back and he continued to act as a tutor with the club.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=222–223}} Wills' former Aboriginal teammates, Mullagh and Cuzens, joined him at the MCC as paid bowlers.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=142}} Wills' physical appearance had deteriorated; gaining weight, balding and generally unkempt, with "an alcoholic blush of his cheeks", he looked older than his years.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2011|1p=187, 226|2a1=de Moore|2y=2008|2p=218}} Describing his body as "stiff" during a cricket match in 1870, he hinted, for the first time, that his talent was fading.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=232}} ==No-ball plot and downfall== {{Quote|text=For Mr. Wills to no-ball Mr. Wardill for throwing is like Satan reproving sin.|sign=Hammersley{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=230}}}} [[File:Tom Wills William Hammersley.jpg|thumb|left|upright|As ''[[The Australasian]]'''s chief sportswriter, Hammersley (standing) led a campaign to have Wills (seated) banned from intercolonial cricket.]] Hardly a year had passed since Wills' return to Australia in 1856 without public comment on his suspect [[bowling action]].{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=76}} As the most famous and outspoken colonial bowler to be accused of throwing, Wills became a "convenient caricature" of the cheat in cricket.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=113–114}} He was cast as a villain for inciting a "plague" of throwing, especially among younger bowlers.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=80–81}} For years his amateur status and "transcendent skill" had protected him, as had the collusion of Victorian newspapers, clubs and spectators, but now an ageing professional, the campaign against his throwing gathered strength. In February 1870, Wills captained Victoria to a 265-run win over New South Wales at the MCG. The match featured [[Twopenny (cricketer)|Twopenny]] (Jarrawuk), an Aboriginal [[fast bowling|paceman]] who was said to have been recruited by Lawrence as a foil to Wills' "chucks".{{sfn|Mallett|2002|p=79}} Comparing the two, the Melbourne press surmised: "Undoubtedly Wills throws sometimes, but there is some decency about it, some disguise."{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=224}} In March, Victoria trounced a Tasmanian XVI in Launceston under Wills' leadership, though not without criticism of his bowling action.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=225}} The accusations of throwing were growing louder, and one-time ally Hammersley, now Melbourne's foremost sportswriter, emerged as Wills' most vocal critic.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=77|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=231}} He accused Wills of resorting to throwing to maintain pace as he aged, and criticised him for introducing a type of [[bouncer (cricket)|bouncer]] designed to injure and intimidate batsmen.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=84}} ''[[The Australasian]]'', Hammersley's newspaper, described Wills' [[modus operandi]]: "If I cannot hit your wicket or make you give a chance soon, I'll hit you and hurt you if I can. I'll frighten you out."{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=84}} In the face of a looming crisis in his career, Wills admitted to throwing in his 1870–71 ''Australian Cricketers' Guide'', and in so doing taunted his enemies to stop him.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=85}} Nonetheless, he was made Victoria XI captain for the March 1871 intercolonial against New South Wales, held at the Albert Ground. Wills' first innings top score of 39* was offset by his drunken behaviour in the field and his apparent reluctance to bowl for fear of being called. Victoria won by 48 runs.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=231–232}} Not long after, Wills was no-balled for throwing for the first time in a club match. Rumour spread that the umpire had conspired against him with the opposing club's owner.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=84|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=233–234}} A series of superb club cricket performances removed any doubt that Wills would play for Victoria in the next intercolonial against New South Wales, scheduled for March 1872 on the MCG.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=241}} Before the game, representatives from both colonies met and entered into a bilateral agreement designed to call Wills.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=86–88}} When he opened the bowling, Wills became the first cricketer to be [[List of cricketers called for throwing in top-class cricket matches in Australia|called for throwing in a top-class Australian match]]. He was called two more times in two overs, and did not bowl again.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=241–242}} He was again no-balled when a Victorian side under his captaincy lost to a combined XIII from New South Wales, Tasmania and South Australia late in 1872.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=244}} Hammersley had seemingly triumphed in his campaign to have Wills banned from intercolonial cricket.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=247}} In an exchange of personal attacks in the press, Wills implied that Hammersley was an architect of the no-ball plot, and protested that he and other English colonists were out to oppress native-born Australians.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=87|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=242}} Wills went on to threaten him with legal action. Hammersley closed:{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=247}} {{quote|You are played out now, the cricketing machine is rusty and useless, all respect for it is gone. You will never be captain of a Victorian Eleven again, ... Eschew colonial beer, and take [[teetotalism|the pledge]], and in time your failings may be forgotten, and only your talents as a cricketer remembered. Farewell, Tommy Wills.}} ==Grace and comeback attempt== [[File:WG Grace 1873.jpg|thumb|upright|An 1873 caricature of [[W. G. Grace]]. In his obituaries, Wills was referred to as "the Grace of Australia".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=7}}]] [[W. G. Grace]], the Victorian era's most famous cricketer, brought an English team to Australia [[W. G. Grace with the English cricket team in Australia in 1873–74|in 1873–74]]. Wills was desperate to play for Victoria against Grace and rival cricketing factions fought over his possible inclusion. Hammersley, a selector, ensured his omission.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=251}} Wills toured with the team, playing for country sides.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=253}} Irked by Wills' constant presence, Grace remarked that he seemed to regard himself as a representative of the whole of Australia.{{sfn|Wills Cooke|2012|p=194}} It was assumed that, on his homeward journey, Grace would play a final match in the South Australian capital of [[Adelaide]], but he bypassed the city when [[Kadina, South Australia|Kadina]], a remote mining town in the [[Copper Coast|Copper Triangle]], offered him more money. Wills coached the locals.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=254–255}} Played in an open, rock-strewn plain of baked earth, the game was deemed a farce. Wills made a [[duck (cricket)#Pair|pair]] and Grace later wrote derisively of the "old Rugbeian" as a has-been.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=262–263}} Grace neglected to mention that Wills bowled him, ending with 6/28.{{sfn|Molony|2000|p=143}} In Geelong, Wills was still idolised, though he seemed discontented, seeking any chance to earn money through cricket in the major cities.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=272–273}} He maintained an interest in the development of football, what he called "the king of games".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=271}} He continued to suggest rule changes, such as the [[push in the back]] rule to curb injuries, and, as captain of Geelong, had shaped the sport's playing style.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=268}} Utilising the young squad's speed and skill, Wills devised an innovative game plan—what he called "scientific football"—based on passing and running into open space.{{sfn|Coventry|2015|p=31–33}} He pioneered another tactical manoeuvre in [[Ballarat]] by controversially ordering his players to [[flooding (Australian football)|flood]] the backline to prevent [[Ballarat Football Club|the home side]] from scoring. He and his men incited the crowd further by wasting time and deliberately kicking the ball out of bounds.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=268–269}} A few years later, in a rare act of diplomacy, Wills quelled tensions after a rival club used his "unchivalrous tactics" against Geelong.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=353}} He played his last football game in 1874.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=270}} The Victoria XI suffered a streak of losses against New South Wales after Wills' downfall.{{sfn|Clowes|2009|p=19}} In his 1874–75 ''Australian Cricketers' Guide'', Wills argued that a new captain was needed to restore Victoria's glory. "No one reading his words could mistake its intent—what Victoria needed was Tom Wills", writes de Moore.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=274}} For the first time in years, the Victorian selection committee shortlisted Wills for the next intercolonial against New South Wales. Noting his faded skills and past transgressions, the Melbourne press lamented, "there is some sentimental notion afloat that as a captain he is peerless."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=276}} Pessimism gave way to hope as Wills promised a win, and in February 1876 he led the Victoria XI onto the Albert Ground. Batting last in the order, he went for 0 and 4 and failed to take a wicket despite bowling the most overs of his side. The media blamed him for Victoria's 195-run loss.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=277}} In turn, he blamed his teammates.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=278}} ==Final years== By 1877, Wills' cricket career "had become a series of petty disputes in petty games" of "ever-deteriorating standards."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=280–282}} No longer an office-bearer with Corio, he moved amongst lower-level clubs in the Geelong area, earning scraps of money wherever he could.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=280–282}} In a brief postscript to one of several rejected applications for employment at the MCC, Wills gave voice to old cricketers "left in the cold". De Moore interpreted the postscript as "an unmistakable backhander for the club." He continues: "To see Wills simply as a beggar would be to misunderstand him."{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=281–282}} Following his retirement as a footballer, Wills turned to umpiring and committee work, and despite his continued slide into debt, donated money and trophies for football competitions.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=270-271}} He served as Geelong's vice-president from 1873 to 1876, and was one of three delegates appointed by the club after the 1877 formation of the [[Victorian Football Association]] (VFA), but was dropped soon after for unknown reasons.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=282, 353}} During the [[1878 VFA season]], he acted as central umpire, and defended his adjudication of a June match between [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] and [[Albert Park Football Club (VFA)|Albert Park]] in what would be his last public letter.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=289–290}} That year, Wills, broke and hounded by creditors, began selling land in Geelong to help clear his debt, and moved with Barbor to [[South Melbourne, Victoria|South Melbourne]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=286, 292}} Wills held no positions of power at the [[South Melbourne Cricket Club]] and only occasionally appeared in local team lists.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=290}} He nonetheless convinced the club to open [[South Melbourne Cricket Ground|its ground]] to football in winter by arguing that it would make the turf firm and durable.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=288–289}} Other clubs soon followed South Melbourne's example and football adapted to an [[Australian rules football playing field|oval-shaped field]].{{sfn|Hess|2008|p=44}} By now, the sport had spread throughout Australasia with Melbourne matches attracting the world's largest football crowds yet seen.{{sfn|Blainey|2003|p=108}} In late 1878, the MCC rejected Wills' last overture to the club, and his dwindling income from cricket was "finally asphyxiated".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=291}} From February 1879 onwards, he lived with Barbor in
