[[Heidelberg, Victoria|Heidelberg]], a small village on the margins of Melbourne. Wills made only two trips outside of Heidelberg for the remainder of his life; on one of these, in January 1880, he was sighted at the MCG during an intercolonial between Victoria and New South Wales.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=294–296}} His alcoholism worsened over this period, as did Barbor's, also a heavy drinker.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=301}} Occasionally he coached the Heidelberg Cricket Club, and, on 13 March 1880, played for the side against a "travelling circus" of [[bohemianism|bohemians]] in his last recorded game. Wills took five wickets, his "chucks" working "sweetly" on the rough pitch.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=281, 297}} In his last surviving letters, sent two days later to his brothers on Cullin-la-ringo, he wrote that he was "out of the world" in Heidelberg, and fantasised about escaping to Tasmania. Begging for money to help pay off debts, he promised, "I will not trouble any of you again".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=299–301}} ===Suicide=== [[File:Melbourne Hospital 1868.jpg|thumb|Wills fled the Melbourne Hospital within hours of his admission.]] Isolated and estranged from most of his family, Wills had become, in the words of cricket historian [[David Frith]], "a complete and dangerous and apparently incurable alcoholic".{{sfn|Frith|2011|p=167}} An oft-repeated story that Wills was housed at [[Kew Asylum|Kew Lunatic Asylum]] near the end of his life is not supported by substantive evidence.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=283–284, 318}} He and Barbor abruptly stopped drinking on 28 April 1880; it is presumed that they ran out of money to buy more alcohol.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=301}} Two days later, Wills started to show signs of [[Alcohol withdrawal syndrome|alcohol withdrawal]], and Barbor, fearing that a calamity was at hand, admitted him to the [[Melbourne Hospital]] on 1 May to be kept under restraint.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=301}} His physician treated him for [[delirium tremens]], but he absconded soon after, returned home and the next day, in the grip of paranoid delusions, committed suicide by stabbing a pair of scissors into his heart three times.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|pp=266–268}} The inquest, on 3 May, presided over by coroner [[Richard Youl]], found that Wills "killed himself when of unsound mind from excessive drinking".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=308–310}} Wills was buried the next day in an unmarked grave in Heidelberg Cemetery at a private funeral attended by only six people: his brother Egbert, sister Emily and cousin Harrison; Harrison's sister Adela and her son Amos; and cricketer [[Verney Cameron]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=310}} His death certificate declared that his parents were unknown.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=291}} When asked by a journalist about her late son, Elizabeth Wills is reported to have denied that Tom ever existed.{{Ref_label|E|e|none}} ==Personality== Wills struck his contemporaries as peculiar and at times [[narcissistic]], with a prickly temperament, but also kind, charismatic and companionable.{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=3|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=xvii|3a1=Blainey|3y=2003|3p=8}} Often embroiled in controversy, he seemed to lack an understanding of how his words and actions could repeatedly get him into trouble.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=193}} His obsession with sport was such that he showed little interest in anything else. Through his research, journalist [[Martin Flanagan (journalist)|Martin Flanagan]] concluded that Wills was "utterly bereft of insight into himself",{{sfn|Judd|2007|p=151}} and football historian Gillian Hibbins described Wills as "an overbearing and undisciplined young man who tended to blame others for his troubles and was more interested in winning a game than in respecting sporting rules."{{sfn|Hibbins|2008|pp=38–39}} Wills' family and peers, though angered by his misbehaviour, frequently forgave him.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=108}} It is unlikely that he sought popular favour, but his strong egalitarian streak helped solidify his folk hero status.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=78, 237}} This affection for him, coupled with an understanding of his waywardness, found expression in the public motto: "With all thy faults I love thee still, Tommy Wills".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=235}} As a young adult back in Australia, Wills developed a peculiar [[stream of consciousness (narrative mode)|stream of consciousness]] style of writing that sometimes defied [[syntax]] and [[grammar]].{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=xvii, 69}} While he spoke in a breezy and laconic manner,{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=185}} his letters are laced with puns, oblique [[Classics|classical]] and [[:wikt:Shakespearean|Shakespearean]] allusions, and droll asides, such as this one about Melbourne in a letter to his brother Cedric: "Everything is dull here, but people are kept alive by people getting shot at in the streets".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=184}} The overall effect is one of "a mind full of energy and histrionic ideas without a centre".{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=69}} {{Quote|text=He could be dismissive, triumphant and brazen all within a single sentence. Whatever his inner world was, he rarely let it be known. Lines of argument or considered opinion were not developed. His stream of thought was in rapid flux and a string of defiant jabs. To give emphasis he underlined his words with a flourish. His punctuation was idiosyncratic. Language was breathless and explosive and he revelled in presenting himself and his motives as mysterious.|sign=Greg de Moore{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=184}}}} In one of his borderline "thought disordered" letters, it is evident that at times he entered a state of [[depersonalisation]]: "I do not know what I am standing on ... when anyone speaks to me I cannot for the life of me make out what they are talking about—everything seems so curious."{{sfnm|1a1=de Moore|1y=2008|1p=184|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=66}} In 1884, Hammersley compared Wills' incipient madness and fiery glare to that of [[Adam Lindsay Gordon]],{{Ref_label|F|f|none}} the Australian [[bush poet]].{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=299}} Wills' mental instability is a source for speculation: [[epilepsy]] has been suggested as a possible cause of his perplexed mental state, and a variant of [[bipolar illness]] may account for his disjointed thinking and flowery, confused writings.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=68, 335}} In 1923, the MCC discovered Wills' old [[cricket cap]] and put it on display in the [[Block Arcade]], prompting Horace Wills to reflect: "My brother was the nicest man I ever met. Though his nature was care-free, amounting almost to wildness, he had the sweetest temper I have seen in a man, and was essentially a sportsman."{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=317–318}} ==Playing style and captaincy== {{Quote|text='Great' athletes seem to be anointed every day; far rarer are those entitled to be considered 'original'. Tom Wills is such a figure in every respect.|sign=[[Gideon Haigh]]{{sfn|Haigh|2009|p=i}}}} [[File:Richmond Paddock 1860.png|thumb|upright|Wills' 1860 "''[[coup de main]]''" has been described as "arguably the most important and influential tactical manoeuvre in the history of Australian football".{{sfn|Coventry|2015|pp=6–7}}]] Wills is regarded as Australia's first outstanding cricketer.{{sfn|Pollard|1987|p=50}} "The picture of the athlete" in his prime, "full to overflowing with animal vigor", Wills seemed indestructible.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article196696327 "Thomas Wentworth Wills"]. ''Leader'' (Melbourne). 8 May 1880. p. 13. Retrieved 15 January 2016. Match reports refer to him as a [[Greek mythology|Greek god]], a [[:wikt:Colossus|Colossus]], "and many other things besides a cricketer".[[Donald Macdonald (journalist)|Macdonald, Donald]]. [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/10177173 "The M. C. C. The Men and the Ground. A Retrospect"]. ''The Argus'' (Melbourne). 19 December 1908. p. 7. Retrieved 15 January 2016. Intensely competitive, his win-at-all-costs mentality, his intimidation of opponents, and his breaking of rules undermined the amateur ideal of friendly competition.{{sfn|Coventry|2015|p=7}} A natural leader, he emboldened his men with his supreme confidence; even in the face of probable defeat, he never despaired the fortunes of his side.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=39}} On the off-chance that he sought another player's opinion, he invariably followed his own mind,{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=97}} and his resources at any critical juncture in a match were said to be always clever, and sometimes unique."Tom Wills". ''[[The Press]]'' (Christchurch). 25 May 1880. p. 3. "As a judge of the game he never had a superior", wrote Britain's ''[[The Sportsman (1865 newspaper)|The Sportsman]]''. He was "at once a cricket crank and genius", according to ''[[The Bulletin]]''.''The Bulletin'' (7 October 1893), "Sporting Notions". p. 17. The rarity of Wills' genius was even compared to [[William Shakespeare]]'s.{{sfn|Hedley|1888|p=7}} The greatest all-rounder of his era, Wills saw himself principally as a bowler. With a repertoire that included "sparklers, rippers, fizzers, trimmers and shooters", he varied his pace and style considerably, and was quick to work out a batsman's weak points.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=62}} Noted for his deceptive slow deliveries, dropping mid-flight and big on break, Wills' fast round arm balls sometimes reared head-high from the pitch, terrorising his opponent. English batsman [[Sir David Serjeant]] said that Wills was the only bowler he ever feared.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2069368 "Early Interstate Cricket"]. ''The Argus'' (Melbourne). 15 November 1924. p. 9. Retrieved 29 April 2015. He was known to carefully study an umpire before deciding whether to throw.[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article154548311 "Game in the Old Days"]. ''Winner'' (Melbourne). 7 March 1917. p. 7. A trickster, he would ask the umpire to watch his feet lest he go over the crease, and then "let go a throw for all he was worth"."The Bowling Trouble". ''The Australasian'' (Melbourne). 2 February 1901. p. 20. His most flagrant throws were likened to that of a [[baseball]] [[pitcher]].[http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28339685 "Baseball As She Is Played"]. ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' (Sydney). 17 December 1888. p. 3. Stiff and "peculiarly ugly" with the bat, Wills was a dogged stonewaller; his characteristic shots—[[batting (cricket)#cuts|cut]]s and to the [[leg side]]—ensured the primacy of defence.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=40}} He explained his technique thus: "The ball can't get through the bat.""Cricket". ''[[Otago Witness]]'' (Dunedin). 7 January 1887. p. 21. He also possessed a capacity for explosive batting, and, according to a contemporary, could "hit as hard as [boxer] [[Tom Sayers]]". On one occasion at the MCG, Wills made a drive into the Richmond Paddock for eight runs. It took two fielders to throw the ball back to wicket.[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/133435472 "Eighty-six Not Out"]. ''Saturday Referee and the Arrow'' (Sydney). 9 March 1912. p. 1. An outstanding fieldsman anywhere, Wills excelled in the [[slip (cricket)|slip]]s and [[run out (cricket)|ran out]] batsmen with deadly accurate throwing.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=38}} Wills was a "tear away" footballer whose "pluck and skill", it was said, only [[George O'Mullane]] matched.{{sfnm|1a1=Pennings|1y=2012|1p=39|2a1=Pennings|2y=2013|2p=1}} The longest [[Drop kick#Australian rules football|drop kick]] in Victoria, he was an elusive dodger, as at Rugby, and excelled in different positions, moving from a follower and goal-scorer in the [[Australian rules football positions#Followers|ruck]] to [[Fullback (Australian rules football)|full back]].{{sfnm|1a1=Coventry|1y=2015|1pp=34–35|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2p=172, 176, 367}} Of the early footballers, Wills was appraised as the greatest, most astute captain, and is credited with opening up the Australian game to new [[Australian football tactics and skills|tactics and skills]] and a more free-flowing style of play.{{sfnm|1a1=Hibbins|1a2=Ruddell|1y=2009|1p=8|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=104–105}} In July 1860—in what the press called a "''[[coup de main]]''", and what has since been recognised as a "tactical leap" that foreshadowed modern football—Wills breached the era's notional offside line by positioning his Richmond men down the field from defence to attack. By a series of short kick passes, they succeeded in scoring.{{sfnm|1a1=Coventry|1y=2015|1pp=6–7|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=104–105}} That same month, captaining Melbourne to victory, he pioneered a rudimentary form of [[flooding (Australian football)|flooding]]; and in another win for the club, exploited the low player turnout by instructing his men to dart with the ball in open spaces.{{sfnm|1a1=Coventry|1y=2015|1p=12, 26|2a1=de Moore|2y=2011|2pp=104–105}} In his season-by-season ranking of players, early football historian C. C. Mullen named Wills "[[Champion of the Colony]]" five times.{{sfn|Mallett|2002|p=21}} Historian [[Bernard Whimpress]] called Wills an innovator who "would fit easily into today's game".[[Bernard Whimpress|Whimpress, Bernard]] (4 August 2015). [http://newtownreviewofbooks.com.au/2015/08/04/james-coventry-time-and-space-the-tactics-that-shaped-australian-rules-and-the-players-and-coaches-who-mastered-them-reviewed-by-bernard-whimpress/ "Time and Space Review"], ''The Newtown Review of Books''. Retrieved 6 March 2016. Historian [[Geoffrey Blainey]] writes: "How many of the tricks and stratagems of the early years came from this clever tactician we will never know."{{sfn|Blainey|2003|p=207}} ==Legacy== {{Cquote|He was buried on the hill top at Heidelberg, overlooking that green valley which, eight years later, [[Arthur Streeton|Streeton]] and [[Tom Roberts|Roberts]] and the painters of the [[Heidelberg School]] would depict in summer colours. A third generation Australian—then a rarity—he had often expressed in football and cricket a version of the national feeling which these artists were to express in paint, and he had been quietly proud that the football game he did so much to shape was often called 'the national game'.|20px||Blainey|''A Game of Our Own''{{sfn|Blainey|2003|p=211}}}} [[File:Tom Wills' Grave.jpg|thumb|The MCC erected a monument over Wills' unmarked gravesite on the centenary of his death. The epitaph reads: "Founder of Australian football and champion cricketer of his time".]] Australia's first celebrity sportsman, Wills began to fade from public consciousness within his own lifetime. His dark reputation and suicide, and his links to convictism and frontier violence—sources of [[cultural cringe]]—have been posited as reasons for his descent into obscurity.{{sfn|Haigh|2009|p=i}} Academic Barry Judd called him "a ghost inhabiting the margins of written history".{{sfn|Judd|2007|p=121}} Coinciding with a revival of interest in Australia's colonial past, Wills has risen "almost to a vogue", and is seen as a forerunner of today's self-destructive star athletes, some of those qualities that alienated his peers "being less shocking to a generation that likes its heroes flawed".{{sfn|Haigh|2009|p=i}} The subject of [[Cultural depictions of Tom Wills|scholarly, literary and artistic works]], his story has been likened to [[bushranger]] [[Ned Kelly]]'s as an epic and quintessentially Australian narrative.{{sfn|Flanagan|2011}} After several attempts by different authors since the 1930s, a comprehensive biography was published in 2008, Greg de Moore's ''Tom Wills: First Wild Man of Australian Sport''.Watt, Jarrod (28 July 2008). [http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2008/07/28/2316731.htm "Investigating the death of the father of football"], [[ABC South West Victoria]]. Retrieved 12 January 2015. Wills' unmarked gravesite was restored in 1980 with a headstone erected by the MCC and by public subscription.[http://monumentaustralia.org.au/australian_monument/display/31621?image=1 Thomas Wentworth Wills], Monument Australia. Retrieved 13 May 2013. He was inducted into the [[Sport Australia Hall of Fame]] in 1989[http://www.sahof.org.au/hall-of-fame/member-profile/?memberID=321&memberType=athlete Thomas Wills], [[Sport Australia Hall of Fame]]. Retrieved 23 February 2015. and was made an inaugural member of the [[Australian Football Hall of Fame]] in 1996. The Tom Wills Room in the MCG's [[Great Southern Stand]] serves as a venue for corporate functions.[http://www.mcg.org.au/Commercial/Corporate%20Hospitality/Cricket%20Premium%20Hospitality/Tom%20Wills%20Room.aspx Tom Wills Room], Melbourne Cricket Ground. Retrieved 4 September 2013. A statue outside the MCG, sculpted by Louis Laumen and erected in 2001, depicts Wills umpiring the famous 1858 football match between Melbourne Grammar and Scotch College.[http://monumentaustralia.org.au/themes/culture/sport/display/32315-first-australian-rules-game First Australian Rules Game], Monument Australia. Retrieved 7 June 2013. The AFL commemorated the 150th anniversary of the match by staging the [[2008 AFL season#Round 19|Tom Wills Round]] during the [[2008 AFL Season]]. The two schools played in a curtain raiser at the MCG ahead of the round opener between Melbourne and Geelong.Harris, Amelia (7 August 2008). [http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/afl/original-and-still-the-best/story-e6frf9jf-1111117137079 "Original and still the best"], ''Herald Sun''. Retrieved 15 August 2013. That same year, Victoria's busiest freeway interchange, the [[Monash Freeway|Monash]]–[[EastLink (Melbourne)|EastLink]] interchange in [[Dandenong North, Victoria|Dandenong North]], was named the Tom Wills Interchange.Ballantyne, Adrian (3 March 2008). [http://dandenong-leader.whereilive.com.au/news/story/legend-rules-the-road/ "Legend rules the road"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927195636/http://dandenong-leader.whereilive.com.au/news/story/legend-rules-the-road/ |date=27 September 2013 }}, ''Dandenong Leader''. Retrieved 15 August 2013. Tom Wills Oval, inaugurated in 2013 at [[Sydney Olympic Park]], serves as the training base for the [[Greater Western Sydney Giants]] of the AFL.[http://www.sopa.nsw.gov.au/resource_centre/park_news/park_news/new_training_facility_for_gws_giants_officially_launched_at_sydney_olympic_park Tom Wills Oval] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130902234618/http://www.sopa.nsw.gov.au/resource_centre/park_news/park_news/new_training_facility_for_gws_giants_officially_launched_at_sydney_olympic_park |date=2 September 2013 }}, Sydney Olympic Park Authority. Retrieved 22 May 2013. ===Marngrook theory=== {{further|Marngrook}} [[File:Marn grook football.jpg|thumb|Detail of an 1857 etching that shows Aboriginal boys kicking and catching a ball made from plant roots.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=322}}]] Since the 1980s, it has been suggested that Wills played or observed an Aboriginal football game, [[Marngrook]],{{Ref_label|G|g|none}} as a child growing up in the Grampians among the Djab wurrung, and incorporated some of its features into early Australian football.{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|2009|p=8}} The theory has provoked intense debate, amounting to a controversy dubbed "football's [[history wars]]".{{sfn|Hocking|Reidy|2016}} In her essay "A Seductive Myth", published in the AFL's ''The Australian Game of Football Since 1858'' (2008), Hibbins calls the proposed link an "emotional belief" lacking "any intellectual credibility".{{sfn|Hibbins|2008|p=45}} She points out that neither Wills nor any of his fellow football founders mention Aboriginal games in existing documents, and states that there is no evidence of Marngrook being played in the vicinity where Wills grew up.{{sfn|Hibbins|2008|p=45}} Since then, among the personal papers of ethnographer [[Alfred William Howitt]], an interview has been found with a [[Wergaia|Mukjarrawaint]] man who recalls playing Marngrook in the Grampians.{{sfn|Hocking|Reidy|2016}} Also, in his first-hand account of Aboriginal games, [[James Dawson (activist)|James Dawson]], an Aboriginal rights activist, records the Djab wurrung word for football as "Min'gorm".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=97}} De Moore therefore argues that Marngrook was likely played around where Wills lived as a boy, "or, at the very least, that the local Aboriginal people knew of such a game". That Wills knew of Marngrook, he adds, is speculative at best.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=323}} Proponents of a link point to the games' similarities, such as [[Punt (Australian football)|drop punting]] the ball and [[spectacular mark|leaping, catching feats]].{{sfn|Hocking|Reidy|2016}} Academics [[Jenny Hocking]] and Nell Reidy write that Wills, in adapting football to Melbourne's parklands, wanted a game that kept the players off the ground and the ball in the air. "It is here", they argue, "in the interstices between rugby and Australian football, that the influence of [Marngrook] can be seen most clearly".{{sfn|Hocking|Reidy|2016}} Historian [[John Hirst (historian)|John Hirst]] countered that early Australian football was aligned with rugby-style roots, and bore little resemblance to Marngrook.{{sfn|Hirst|2010|p=55}} According to de Moore, Wills was "almost solely influenced" by Rugby School football, with local conditions also having an effect.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=323}} Flanagan promoted the Marngrook theory in his novel ''[[The Call (Martin Flanagan novel)|The Call]]'' (1996), an historical imagining into Wills' life,{{sfn|Flanagan|2011}} and argued in an essay addressed to Wills that he must have known Aboriginal games as it was in his nature to play: "There's two things about you everybody seems to have agreed on—you'd drink with anyone and you'd play with anyone."{{sfn|Flanagan|2008|p=543}} He quotes Lawton Wills Cooke, a descendent of Horace Wills (Tom's brother), who said a family story had been passed down about Tom playing Marngrook as a boy.Flanagan, Martin (27 December 2008). [http://www.theage.com.au/news/sport/a-new-chapter-in-the-legend-of-tom-wills/2008/12/26/1229998734179.html "A new chapter in the legend of Tom Wills"], ''The Age''. Retrieved 21 October 2012. Family historian T. S. Wills Cooke disputed that such a story existed, calling the Marngrook link "a bridge too far" and a [[political correctness|politically correct]] attempt to rewrite history.{{sfn|Wills Cooke|2012|p=180}} Despite lacking in hard evidence, the theory is often presented as factual.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=93}} In [[Moyston, Victoria|Moyston]], the self-proclaimed birthplace of Australian football,{{sfn|Hirst|2010|p=55}} stands an AFL-endorsed monument, unveiled by historian [[Col Hutchinson]], commemorating Wills' childhood in the area playing Marngrook.[http://monumentaustralia.org.au/themes/people/sport/display/32785-thomas-wentworth-wills-/photo/1 Thomas Wentworth Wills], Monument Australia. Retrieved 4 October 2016. ==="Father of football"=== [[File:Tom wills statue.jpg|thumb|upright|Statue outside the MCG of Wills umpiring the 1858 game between Melbourne Grammar and Scotch College. The plaque reads that Wills "did more than any other person—as a footballer and umpire, co-writer of the rules and promoter of the game—to develop Australian football during its first decade."]] The role that Wills and others played in pioneering Australian football went largely unrecognised in their lifetimes as the sport had yet to develop a historical perspective.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=324}} In an 1876 piece on the Melbourne Football Club's origins, published in ''The Australasian'', Wills' 1858 letter calling for the organisation and codification of football was noted as a seminal document.[http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/142158224 "THE ORIGIN OF THE MELBOURNE CLUB"]. ''The Australasian'' (Melbourne). 26 February 1876. p. 13. Retrieved 2 August 2015. Wills later wrote that he attempted to promote football in Victoria as early as 1857, "but it was not taken to kindly until the following year".{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|2009|p=13}} By 1908, the year of Australian football's [[1908 Melbourne Carnival|jubilee celebrations]], H. C. A. Harrison was proclaimed "the father of football" on account of his substantial reputation on and off the field.{{sfn|Hibbins|Ruddell|2009|pp=12–13}} Wills was the next most often recalled pioneer during this period,{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=323–324}} and Harrison credited him with initiating the sport when he "recommended that we Australians should work out a game of our own."Harrison, H. C. A. (12 August 1914). [http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/155522568 "Australian Game: Its Birth in the Commonwealth"]. ''Winner'' (Melbourne). p. 8. Retrieved 3 May 2016. More recent historiography has shown that while Harrison was a pivotal figure over a long period, he did not co-write the first rules in 1859 and did not play in the 1858 games. With this correction, Wills was elevated to a position of pre-eminence.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=324}} He has variously been called the game's father and inventor.{{sfnm|1a1=Molony|1y=2000|1p=145|2a1=Hess|2y=2008|2p=26}} Blainey said of Wills: "It is far too much to say that he founded the game, but it would be too little to say that he was simply one among many founders."{{sfn|Blainey|2003|p=206}} It is often said that, due to his suicide, Wills was written out of the game's history, or at the very least downplayed as an important figure. De Moore has challenged this view by noting that it was the contributions of Hammersley, Smith, Thompson and other pioneers, rather than those of Wills, that were generally overlooked.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=324}} In her analysis of early football, Hibbins concludes that Thompson's journalistic ability as a promoter of the game "probably" makes him the most significant pioneer, and that the importance of Wills' role has been over-emphasised.{{sfn|Hibbins|2008|p=32, 41}} Echoing Hibbins' arguments, Roy Hay writes that Wills, while a "catalyst" for football, was "much more interested in playing and performing than in organising".{{sfn|Hay|2008|p=29}} British historian [[Tony Collins (historian)|Tony Collins]] even compared Wills to [[William Webb Ellis]] and [[Abner Doubleday]], the apocryphal inventors of rugby and baseball respectively.{{sfn|Collins|2011|p=11}} In response to Collins' suggestion that Wills "quickly faded from the footballing scene", [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] journalist [[James Coventry]] drew attention to his seventeen-year playing career (by far the longest of the pioneers), the influence he wielded as captain-coach of various clubs for much of that time, and his administrative work. He concludes that Collins and other scholars have "perversely" devalued Wills' real contributions "in their rush to discredit [the Marngrook theory]".{{sfn|Coventry|2015|pp=28–29}} ==See also== *[[Cultural depictions of Tom Wills]] *[[List of Australian rules footballers and cricketers]] *[[List of cricketers called for throwing in top-class cricket matches in Australia]] *[[List of Victoria first-class cricketers]] ==Footnotes== {{refbegin|2}} '''a.''' {{Note_label|A|a|none}} Wills' birthplace is a matter of some conjecture as there is a dearth of reliable archival information on the subject, and the precise whereabouts of his parents are difficult to pinpoint during the period around 1835.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=171}} Molonglo is given as his birthplace in an [[s:Mr Thomas W. Wills: A Biographical Sketch|1869 biographical piece]] in which William Hammersley, the author, states that Wills had furnished him with notes.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=328}} A common alternative is [[Parramatta]].{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=171}} When Victorians claimed Wills as one of theirs, he liked to boast that he was a "Sydney man"—a reference to the colony of his birth.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=81–82}} '''b.''' {{Note_label|B|b|none}} Tom had eight siblings: Emily Spencer Wills (1842–1925), Cedric Spencer Wills (1844–1914), Horace Spencer Wills (1847–1928), Egbert Spencer Wills (1849–1931), Elizabeth Spencer Wills (1852–1930), Eugenie Spencer Wills (1854–1937), Minna Spencer Wills (1856–1943) and Hortense Sarah Spencer Wills (1861–1907).{{sfn|Wills Cooke|2012|p=250}} '''c.''' {{Note_label|C|c|none}} Wills and H. C. A. Harrison shared Sarah Howe as a grandmother.{{sfn|Hibbins|Mancini|1987|p=5}} Harrison was born ten months after Wills in New South Wales and as a young boy overlanded to the Port Phillip District, where he often visited the Wills family at Lexington.{{sfn|Blainey|2003|p=68–69}} They became brothers-in-law in 1864 when Harrison married Emily Wills.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|pp=172–173}} '''d.''' {{Note_label|D|d|none}} The Aborigines went by sobriquets given to them by their European employers in the Western District.{{sfn|de Moore|2011|p=192}} In Mullagh's case, he was named after the station where he worked.{{sfn|Mallett|2002|p=18}} '''e.''' {{Note_label|E|e|none}} This story was related in the following piece of Wills family oral history: "Elizabeth Wills refused to attend [the funeral] nor would she acknowledge Tom after his death as she was very religious and considered [suicide] a great sin. ... A reporter asked Elizabeth about her son. 'Which son?' she asked. 'Thomas' said the reporter. 'I have no son called Thomas' was the old lady's reply".{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=303}} '''f.''' {{Note_label|F|f|none}} Gordon suffered a demise similar to that of Wills, committing suicide in 1870.{{sfn|de Moore|2008|p=299}} He describes Wills as a fearsome bowler in his 1865 long poem "Ye Wearie Wayfarer".{{sfn|Blainey|2003|p=210}} '''g.''' {{Note_label|G|g|none}} Each Indigenous language group played its own variant of football and with its own name.{{sfn|Hocking|Reidy|2016}} "Marngrook", from the [[Gunditjmara]] [[Kuurn Kopan Noot language|language]], is used as a generic term for Aboriginal football.{{sfn|Hirst|2010|p=54}} {{refend}} == References == {{Reflist|3}} ==Bibliography== '''Books''' {{Refbegin}} * {{cite book |ref = harv |last = Blainey |first = Geoffrey |authorlink [[Edwin Edwards]]
[[Murphy J. Foster Jr.|Mike Foster]]
[[Kathleen Blanco]] | term_start = December 1988 | term_end = July 15, 2005 | preceded = [[James H. "Jim" Brown]] | succeeded = [[Al Ater]] | office2 = [[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana State Representative from Caldwell, Franklin, Jackson, and Winn parishes]] | term_start2 = 1984 | term_end2 = 1988 | preceded2 = [[Thomas "Bud" Brady]] | succeeded2 = [[Noble Ellington]] | birth_place = [[Columbia, Louisiana]], U.S. | birth_date = {{birth date|1946|9|8}} | death_place = [[Baton Rouge, Louisiana]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2005|7|16|1946|9|8}} | resting_place = Hogan Cemetery
Columbia, Louisiana | nationality = American | occupation = [[Teacher|Educator]]; [[business]]man | alma_mater = Caldwell Parish High School
[[Louisiana Tech University]] {{small|(BA)}} | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] (1989{{endash}}2005) | otherparty = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] (before 1989) | religion = [[United Methodist Church|United Methodist]] | children = Marjorie A. McKeithen, Marianne McKeithen, Rebecca McKeithen, John McKeithen}} '''Walter Fox McKeithen''' (September 8, 1946 – July 16, 2005) served five terms as [[Secretary of State of Louisiana]] between 1988 and 2005. He is best known for merging the state's election divisions into one department and for the promotion of historical preservation. ==Early life and education== McKeithen was born in rural [[Columbia, Louisiana]] to [[John McKeithen|John Julian McKeithen]] and the former Marjorie Howell Funderburk. According to his tombstone, he was named for two [[World War II]] heroes, Walter Bennett and Elmer Fox. He graduated as class president in 1964 from Caldwell Parish High School, the same month in which his father was inaugurated as [[Governors of Louisiana|governor of Louisiana]]. One of his classmates was future associate justice of the [[Louisiana Supreme Court]], [[Chet D. Traylor]]. McKeithen attended [[Louisiana Tech University]] in [[Ruston, Louisiana|Ruston]] in [[Lincoln Parish, Louisiana|Lincoln Parish]] to obtain a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[history]] and [[social studies]]. After graduating from Louisiana Tech, McKeithen returned to Caldwell Parish High School, located off [[U.S. Route 165]], as a civics teacher and [[coach (sport)|coach]]. He also established three businesses in Caldwell Parish.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} ==Democrat for secretary of state, 1987== In 1983, McKeithen was elected to the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] when the incumbent [[Thomas "Bud" Brady]] of [[La Salle Parish, Louisiana|La Salle Parish]] was shifted into District 22, where he defeated sitting Representative [[Richard S. Thompson]] and former legislator [[W.L. Rambo]].{{cite web|url=http://staticresults.sos.la.gov/10221983/10221983_Legislative.html|title=Louisiana primary election returns, October 22, 1983|publisher=staticresults.sos.la.gov|accessdate=July 5, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://staticresults.sos.la.gov/11191983/11191983_42239.html|title=Louisiana general election returns, November 19, 1983|publisher=staticresults.sos.la.gov|accessdate=July 5, 2013}} In 1987, McKeithen was elected secretary of state. In the [[nonpartisan blanket primary]], McKeithen led with 462,965 votes (34 percent) to 365,151 (27 percent) for his principal challenger, fellow Democrat Mike Cutshaw, an attorney for the Louisiana Bankers Association. Two [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidates, M. A. "Mike" Tassin and Bobby A. Patrick,"Secretary of State's post a stepping stone?", ''[[Minden Press-Herald]]'', October 18, 1987, p. 3 shared 13 percent of the vote, and two other Democrats held a combined 19 percent. Three "no party" candidates polled 8 percent. In the [[general election]], McKeithen only narrowly prevailed over Cutshaw, 490,190 (51 percent) to 467,582 (49 percent).Louisiana Secretary of State, Primary election returns, October 24, 1987 ==Republican for Secretary of State, 1991== In the summer of 1989, McKeithen switched to the Republican Party, whose chairman, [[William "Billy" Nungesser]], had courted him for a possible 1990 campaign for the [[United States Senate]] against the Democrat [[Bennett Johnston|J. Bennett Johnston, Jr.]]"Republicans courting McKeithen", ''Minden Press-Herald'', July 14, 1989, p. 1 Upon making the party switch, the GOP helped McKeithen pay off $400,000 in campaign debts."GOP wins McKeithen", ''Minden Press-Herald'', July 27, 1989, p. 1 McKeithen announced that he would run for the Senate"McKeithen challenges Johnston", ''Minden Press-Herald'', November 7, 1989, p. 1 but dropped such plans when the Republican state convention on January 13, 1990, endorsed [[Louisiana State Senate|State Senator]] [[Ben Bagert]] of [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] as the party's preferred candidate. Ultimately, Johnston was reelected in a showdown with another Republican, the maverick [[David Duke]], a former figure in the [[Ku Klux Klan]]. Bagert left the race two days before the election at the request of national Republican leaders, who endorsed Johnston over Duke. In the 1972 general election, John McKeithen had run as an [[Independent (politics)|Independent]] for the Senate in an unsuccessful race against Johnston. Fox McKeithen's father and daughter, Marjorie A. McKeithen (born 1965), both opposed the party switch and remained Democrat.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} In 1991, McKeithen faced a close contest for reelection as secretary of state. Two Democrats, Mary Chehardy (later a Republican) and Doug Schmidt, challenged him. McKeithen led in the primary, with 629,237 votes (46 percent) to Schmidt's 387,243 (28 percent). Close behind was Chehardy with 357,173 (26 percent). Schmidt, who used the expression "Get the Fox out of the Henhouse", advanced to the general election against McKeithen. In the showdown, McKeithen prevailed by 9,151 votes, a margin similar to [[David C. Treen]]'s plurality over Democrat [[Louis Lambert]] in the 1979 gubernatorial contest. Returns gave McKeithen 827,506 votes to Schmidt's 818,355.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} In subsequent elections, McKeithen was often endorsed by Democrats and worked well with members from both parties. His folksy manner meant that he was generally popular with voters despite adopting such unpopular positions as raising the pay of elected state officials. In his last race in 2003, he even carried the endorsement of [[organized labor]], which rarely supports Republicans. During January 2004, McKeithen supervised the combining of the former elections department into the secretary of state's office.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} A few weeks later, when voting machines were slow to arrive in [[New Orleans]] in time for the 2004 elections, he helped to deliver them himself. McKeithen's gravestone in Caldwell Parish lists his principal accomplishments as the restoration of the Old State Capitol in Baton Rouge, the Cotton Museum in [[Lake Providence, Louisiana|Lake Providence]], the [[Delta Music Museum]] in [[Ferriday, Louisiana|Ferriday]], and the Louisiana Exhibition Building in [[Shreveport, Louisiana|Shreveport]].{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} ==Death== {{unreferenced section|date=June 2015}} After a fall in the garage of his home in Baton Rouge in February 2005, McKeithen was hospitalized with paralysis from the neck down. Trouble struck again, and he re-entered the hospital on June 21 with a serious infection caused from the fall. He resigned as secretary of state on July 15, 2005, and died just a few hours later. He left his state pension to his widow, Yvonne Y. McKeithen. [[Al Ater|Alan Ray Ater]], a former state representative from [[Ferriday, Louisiana|Ferriday]] in [[Concordia Parish]] became the acting secretary of state on McKeithen's death by virtue of having been the first deputy secretary of state. Ater did not seek the position in the [[special election]] held on September 30, 2006, to fill the remaining fifteen months of McKeithen's term. Late in 2006, Ater hence turned over the office to Republican state Senator [[Jay Dardenne]] (pronounced DAR DEN) of Baton Rouge. Dardenne was declared the winner of the special election after the runner-up candidate, outgoing Democratic state Senator [[Francis C. Heitmeier]] of [[New Orleans]] withdrew from a pending [[runoff election]], which would have coincided with the November 7 national general election. In the September 30 election, Dardenne led with 30 percent of the vote. He ran up large margins in the greater Baton Rouge area and finished second in other portions of the state. Heitmeier, who ran best in [[Liberalism|liberal]] and labor areas of the state, trailed with 28 percent. A third candidate, the [[conservatism|conservative]] former Louisiana Republican State Chairman [[Mike Francis (politician)|Mike Francis]] of [[Crowley, Louisiana|Crowley]] in [[Acadia Parish]], finished with 26 percent of the ballots. He ran well in Acadiana and his native north Louisiana — he is originally from [[Jena, Louisiana|Jena]] in [[La Salle Parish]] - but trailed badly in Baton Rouge, New Orleans, and the [[Florida Parishes]]. [[Image:Fox McKeithen grave, Caldwell Parish, Louisiana IMG 2741.JPG|200px|right|thumb|Fox McKeithen is interred beside his father, mother, and older brother at the private Hogan Cemetery off Louisiana Highway 559 in [[Caldwell Parish, Louisiana|Caldwell Parish]]]] ==Legacy== In 2006, McKeithen was inducted [[Posthumous recognition|posthumously]] into the [[Louisiana Political Museum and Hall of Fame]] in Winnfield, an honor that his father had procured in 1993, having been among the first thirteen honorees. {{Portalbar|Biography|Louisiana|Education|History|Politics|Methodism}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Links== * [http://www.shreveporttimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20050716/NEWS/50716001 ''Shreveport Times'' report on death July 16, 2005] {{paywall}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060220203521/http://www.sec.state.la.us/admin/biography.htm Biography as Secretary of State] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060220053200/http://www.bayoubuzz.com/articles.aspx?aid=4515] * [http://www.sos.louisiana.gov:8090/cgibin/?rqstyp=elcms2&rqsdta=101991]{{dead link|date=December 2012}} ==External links== *{{findagrave|11367826}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-la-hs}} {{succession box | before = [[Thomas "Bud" Brady]] | title = [[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana State Representative from Caldwell, Franklin, Jackson, and Winn parishes]] | years = 1984–1988 | after = [[Noble Ellington]] }} {{s-off}} {{succession box | before = [[James H. "Jim" Brown]] | title = [[Louisiana Secretary of State]] | years = 1988–2005 | after = [[Al Ater]] }} {{s-end}} {{Louisiana Political Museum and Hall of Fame}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McKeithen, W.
